questionOriginal: Can I take ibuprofen for COVID-19 symptoms?
questionText: Can I take ibuprofen for COVID-19 symptoms?
answerOriginal:
Some early news reports suggested that non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs), such as ibuprofen, could worsen coronavirus disease. However, the Food and Drug Administration (FDA) has said it is not aware of any scientific evidence connecting the use of NSAIDs with worsening COVID-19 symptoms at this time. The FDA is investigating this issue further.

There are multiple medicines you can buy with or without a doctorâs prescription that are approved for pain relief and fever reduction. Please read warning labels on all medications before using them and consult with your health care provider about what is best for you.

questionOriginal: How can community helpers and volunteers keep from getting sick with COVID-19?
questionText: How can community helpers and volunteers keep from getting sick with COVID-19?
answerOriginal:
Making sure neighbors have what they need is crucial, but we need to make sure helpers and volunteers are still taking precautions to protect our most vulnerable Vermonters. Common sense practices can go a long way while Vermonters take care of each other.

The Vermont Department of Health recommends any volunteers bringing items to those who need to stay home:

  • Keep a distance of 6 feet away.

  • Avoid entering the personâs home.

  • Wear a cloth face mask or covering.

  • Wash your hands regularly.

  • Avoid touching your face and cover your cough or sneeze with a tissue, then throw the tissue in the trash.

  • Stop doing community support work immediately if you feel sick or find out you have had contact with someone who is sick.

  • Keep a list of anyone you come into close contact with in case contact tracing is required.

  • Wear clean gloves when handling items that may be given to people with a weaker immune system, and when you are close to someone who may be sick.

Avoid entering the personâs home.


Wear a cloth face mask or covering.

questionOriginal: Should I avoid contact with pets or other animals if I am sick with COVID-19?
questionText: Should I avoid contact with pets or other animals if I am sick with COVID-19?
answerOriginal:
If you are sick with COVID-19 (either suspected or confirmed by a test), avoid contact with your pets and other animals, just like you would around other people.

  • When possible, have another member of your household care for your pets while you are sick.

  • Avoid contact with your pet, including petting, snuggling, being kissed or licked, and sharing food or bedding.

  • If you must care for your pet or be around animals while you are sick, wear a cloth face mask or covering and wash your hands before and after you interact with them.

Learn more about what to do if you have animals from the CDC.

Find more information on preparing for your pet from the CDC.

Read the COVID-19 FAQs for pet owners from the American Veterinary Medical Association.

questionOriginal: How can I take care of myself, my family, or friends with the stress from COVID-19?
questionText: How can I take care of myself, my family, or friends with the stress from COVID-19?
answerOriginal:
Feeling anxious, confused, overwhelmed or powerless is common during an infectious disease outbreak. Taking care of yourself, your friends, and your family can help you cope with stress. Helping others cope with their stress can also make your community stronger.

  • Take breaks from watching, reading, or listening to news stories, including social media. Hearing about the pandemic repeatedly can be upsetting.

  • Take care of your body. Take deep breaths, stretch, or meditate. Try to eat healthy, well-balanced meals, exercise regularly, get plenty of sleep, and avoid alcohol and drugs.

  • Make time to unwind. Try to do some other activities you enjoy.

  • Connect with others. Talk with people you trust about your concerns and how you are feeling.

Find more information on coping with COVID-19 stress, including resources for local help, self-care, suicide prevention, and domestic violence.

Find more tips for coping with stress from the CDC, including how to help children cope with stress.

Need support right now?

  • Call your local mental health crisis line

  • Text VT to 741741

  • Call 2-1-1 or 1-866-652-4636

  • Contact the National Suicide Prevention Lifeline or call 1-800-273-8255

  • For multilingual support, call 800-985-5990 or text TalkWithUs to 66746

questionOriginal: How can I prepare at home?
questionText: How can I prepare at home?
answerOriginal:
• Plan ways to care for those in your home who might be at greater risk for serious complications, like older adults (65 years and older) and people of any age who have underlying medical conditions. Make sure those who need regular medicine, medical supplies and equipment have what they need.

  • Choose a room in your home that can be used to separate sick household members from those who are healthy. Identify a separate bathroom for the sick person to use, if possible. Plan to clean these rooms, as needed, when someone is sick.

  • Make sure you have enough groceries and other supplies for 14 days in case you get sick and need to quarantine. Stock up on only what you will need for 14 days. Do not buy more than you will need so you can leave supplies for other people.

  • Get support from others. Talk with your neighbors about emergency planning. If your neighborhood has Front Porch Forum, consider joining to connect with neighbors, information and resources. Stay in touch by phone or email with family and friends, especially those who are 65 years and older, who have underlying medical conditions, or who live alone.

  • Take care of the emotional health of your household members. Outbreaks can be stressful for adults and children. Talk with your children about the outbreak, try to stay calm, and reassure them that they are safe.

  • Keep a daily list of other people you are in close contact with. As the state reopens, Vermonters should consider keeping a contact journal. If you do get sick, this would make it easier to get in touch with those people and so they can take proper precautions to prevent further spread of COVID-19.

Read Preventing COVID-19: Tips for Large Households or Extended Families Living in the Same Space.

questionOriginal: Why is race and ethnicity now included in reported data on COVID-19 cases?
questionText: Why is race and ethnicity now included in reported data on COVID-19 cases?
answerOriginal:
The Health Department is now including data about race and ethnicity on the Current Activity in Vermont data dashboard. We recognized the need to include this information to help us understand how Vermonters were being affected by COVID-19, but in our earlier efforts to respond to the pandemic, race and ethnicity data was not always collected for each patient. A Weekly Summary of Vermont COVID-19 Data is also available that includes more details on who has been impacted by COVID-19 in Vermont.

Health equity exists when all people have a fair and just opportunity to be healthy â especially those who have experienced socioeconomic disadvantage, historical injustice, and other systemic inequalities. Therefore, our epidemiology team collaborated with Vermont Information Technology Leaders (VITL) to cross-reference medical records to gain more robust race information about COVID-19 cases in Vermont.

We can use this data to help to prevent the spread of illness, improve care for patients, and present a more complete picture of how COVID-19 may be affecting everyone in Vermont.

The Health Department is now including data about race and ethnicity on the Current Activity in Vermont data dashboard. We recognized the need to include this information to help us understand how Vermonters were being affected by COVID-19, but in our earlier efforts to respond to the pandemic, race and ethnicity data was not always collected for each patient. A Weekly Summary of Vermont COVID-19 Data is also available that includes more details on who has been impacted by COVID-19 in Vermont.
Health equity exists when all people have a fair and just opportunity to be healthy â especially those who have experienced socioeconomic disadvantage, historical injustice, and other systemic inequalities. Therefore, our epidemiology team collaborated with Vermont Information Technology Leaders (VITL) to cross-reference medical records to gain more robust race information about COVID-19 cases in Vermont.
We can use this data to help to prevent the spread of illness, improve care for patients, and present a more complete picture of how COVID-19 may be affecting everyone in Vermont.

questionOriginal: What should families do if they are not able to get formula, diapers, or other baby necessities?
questionText: What should families do if they are not able to get formula, diapers, or other baby necessities?
answerOriginal:
Families can call Help Me Grow-VT at 2-1-1 ext. 6 to be directed to services in their area that may be able to assist with formula, diapers, or other necessities.

Vermont WIC provides healthy foods, nutrition education, and breastfeeding support to pregnant and postpartum Vermonters and caregivers of infants and children under 5. Vermont WIC is open and invites new and returning families to join. If your family financial circumstances have changed due to a job loss or reduced hours, you could be eligible for WIC.

WIC has made a few changes to keep families and staff safe during the COVID-19 pandemic. All appointments are being done by phone and breastfeeding classes are offered online.

Apply for WIC online or text VTWIC to 855-11. You can also connect with WIC in your area.

Food banks and food shelves may be resources for families not eligible for WIC. Find more information on food access from Hunger Free Vermont.

Find more resources for families with children.

questionOriginal: What is serologic, or antibody, testing and will it be used in Vermont?
questionText: What is serologic, or antibody, testing and will it be used in Vermont?
answerOriginal:
Serologic testing measures antibodies in the blood of a person who has been infected with COVID-19, whether they felt sick or not. In other words, it measures the bodyâs immune response to the virus, but does not detect the virus itself. According to the FDA, in the early days of an infection when the bodyâs immune response is still building, antibodies may not be detected. This limits the testâs effectiveness for diagnosing COVID-19 and why it should not be used as the sole basis to diagnose COVID-19.

With any test, there is always a risk of incorrect test results â false positive and false negative results. We need a good and accurate test we can rely on. The Vermont Department of Health convened a working group of experts to research antibody tests. Their findings conclude that at this time, the serologic (antibody) tests that are currently available are not accurate or reliable enough. Based on these findings, they caution against using serologic testing to make decisions about individuals. For example, using this test to establish âproof of immunity.â However, this type of test could help us better understand the population-level rate of infection from COVID-19 in Vermont.

We will continue to use public health best practice â considering clinical data, exposure history, and what is happening at the community-level â to make decisions on when to reopen businesses and when to return to work. The working group will continue to meet regularly and will be watching closely for changes and improvements in serologic testing. Recommendations may change based on new data.
answerText:
Serologic testing measures antibodies in the blood of a person who has been infected with COVID-19, whether they felt sick or not. In other words, it measures the bodyâs immune response to the virus, but does not detect the virus itself.
With any test, there is always a risk of incorrect test results â false positive and false negative results. We need a good and accurate test we can rely on. The Vermont Department of Health convened a working group of experts to research antibody tests. Their findings conclude that at this time, the serologic (antibody) tests that are currently available would not produce results that are accurate or reliable enough in Vermont. The working group will continue to meet regularly and will be watching closely for changes and improvements in serologic testing. Recommendations may change based on new data.
Though certain providers may offer antibody testing in Vermont, the working group cautions against using serologic testing to make decisions about individuals, for example, using this test to establish âproof of immunity.â However, this type of test could help us better understand the population-level rate of infection from COVID-19 in Vermont.

questionOriginal: Why is it okay to end quarantine after seven days with a negative test result?
questionText: Why is it okay to end quarantine after seven days with a negative test result?
answerOriginal: Studies have found most people will develop symptoms by Day 7. This why there is the option for people to be tested at Day 7 or after in their quarantine and, if the test is negative, to end quarantine. The test must be a PCR test.

questionOriginal: Are there any travel restrictions if I am traveling through Vermont?
questionText: Are there any travel restrictions if I am traveling through Vermont?
answerOriginal: If you are only traveling through and not staying in Vermont (for example, driving through Vermont to another state, flying to Vermont and immediately picking up a rental car to drive to another state), there are no quarantine or other restrictions you need to follow. If you need to make stops in Vermont or are otherwise not in a vehicle while you are traveling through Vermont, please follow these general precautions to help prevent the spread of the virus: wear a cloth face mask or covering, keep a 6-foot distance from others, and wash your hands often.
answerText: If you are only traveling through and not staying in Vermont (for example, driving through Vermont to another state, flying to Vermont and immediately picking up a rental car to drive to another state), there are no quarantine or other restrictions you need to follow. If you need to make stops in Vermont or are otherwise not in a vehicle while you are traveling through Vermont, please follow these general precautions to help prevent the spread of the virus: wear a cloth face mask or covering, keep a 6-foot distance from others, and wash your hands often.

questionOriginal: What is a PCR test?
questionText: What is a PCR test?
answerOriginal:
A PCR test is the most common type of COVID-19 test used today. PCR stands for polymerase chain reaction. The test identifies people who are currently infected with the COVID-19 virus.

PCR tests are generally the most reliable tests. Samples are analyzed at a lab, which usually takes up to a few days. A PCR test is used at pop-up testing sites offered by the Health Department.

Data on COVID-19 activity reported by the Health Department includes only PCR tests.

The PCR test used by the Vermont Department of Health Laboratory has a sensitivity rate of 95%, which means the test correctly gives a positive result 95% of the time. Sensitivity rates may be different at other labs.

questionOriginal: When can I stop self-isolating (home isolation)?
questionText: When can I stop self-isolating (home isolation)?
answerOriginal:
People with COVID-19 who have stayed home (home isolated) can stop home isolation under the following conditions:

If you will not have a test to determine if you are still contagious, you can leave home after these three things have happened:

  • you have had no fever for at least 72 hours (that is three full days of no fever without the use medicine that reduces fevers) AND

  • other symptoms have improved (for example, when your cough or shortness of breath have improved) AND

  • at least 10 days have passed since your symptoms first appeared

If you will be tested to determine if you are still contagious, you can leave home after these three things have happened:

  • you no longer have a fever (without the use medicine that reduces fevers) AND

  • other symptoms have improved (for example, when your cough or shortness of breath have improved) AND

  • you received two negative tests in a row, 24 hours apart.

Your doctor will follow CDC guidelines. In all cases, follow the guidance of your health care provider and the Health Department. The decision to stop home isolation should be made in consultation with your health care provider and the Health Department.
answerText:
People with COVID-19 who have stayed home (home isolated) can stop home isolation under the following conditions:
If you had symptoms, you can leave home and be with others after these three things have happened (unless otherwise instructed by your health care provider:

you have had no fever for at least 24 hours without the use medicine that reduces fevers AND
other symptoms have improved (for example, when your cough or shortness of breath have improved) AND
at least 10 days have passed since your symptoms first appeared

If you did not have any symptoms, you can leave home and be with others after:

10 days have passed since the date you had your positive test (unless otherwise instructed by your health care provider).

Your health care provider will follow CDC guidelines. In all cases, follow the guidance of your health care provider and the Health Department. The decision to stop home isolation should be made in consultation with your health care provider and the Health Department.
After stopping home isolation, continue to follow the general precautions to help keep the virus from spreading:Â wear aÂ cloth face mask or covering, keep a 6-foot distance from others you donât live with, wash your hands often, and stay home if you are sick.

questionOriginal: Can I wear a face shield instead of a face mask or covering?
questionText: Can I wear a face shield instead of a face mask or covering?
answerOriginal:
As of August 1, you are required to wear a face mask or covering in public spaces in Vermont any time it is not possible to keep a 6-foot distance from others who are not part of your household. In private settings with people you donât live with, we recommend that you wear a face mask or covering when itâs not possible to stay 6 feet apart. However, for some people, and in some cases, a face shield may be an option.

The virus that causes COVID-19 is thought to spread mainly from person-to-person, by respiratory droplets released when an infected person talks, coughs, or sneezes. Face shields are typically used in health care settings to protect the person wearing it from droplets getting into their eyes. Face masks or coverings, like a cloth face mask or bandanna, do a better job than face shields of keeping droplets in and not spreading the virus.

If you have trouble breathing or if you work in a setting where it is difficult to wear a face mask or covering, wearing a face shield is better than wearing nothing over your nose and mouth. People who have trouble breathing can also wear a light-weight bandanna or cloth covering tied to be open at the bottom. In school settings, students and adults are allowed to wear face shields, and in child care settings, providers, teachers and staff are allowed to wear face shields.

Face shields should extend below the chin, to the ears on both sides, and there should be no exposed gap between the forehead and the shieldâs headpiece. Clean them regularly â especially if condensation or droplets are visible on the inside of the shield â and handle them like face masks or coverings when putting them on or removing them. (see âWhat is the correct way to wear a face mask or covering?â on this page for more details).
answerText:
As of August 1, you are required to wear a face mask or covering in public spaces in Vermont any time it is not possible to keep a 6-foot distance from others who are not part of your household. In private settings with people you donât live with, we recommend that you wear a face mask or covering when itâs not possible to stay 6 feet apart. However, for some people, and in some cases, a face shield may be an option.
The virus that causes COVID-19 is thought to spread mainly from person-to-person, by respiratory droplets released when an infected person talks, coughs, or sneezes. Face shields are typically used in health care settings to protect the person wearing it from droplets getting into their eyes. Face masks or coverings, like a cloth face mask or bandanna, do a better job than face shields of keeping droplets in and not spreading the virus.
If you have trouble breathing or if you work in a setting where it is difficult to wear a face mask or covering, wearing a face shield is better than wearing nothing over your nose and mouth. People who have trouble breathing can also wear a light-weight bandanna or cloth covering tied to be open at the bottom. In school settings, students and adults are allowed to wear face shields, and in child care settings, providers, teachers and staff are allowed to wear face shields.
Face shields should extend below the chin, to the ears on both sides, and there should be no exposed gap between the forehead and the shieldâs headpiece. Clean them regularly â especially if condensation or droplets are visible on the inside of the shield â and handle them like face masks or coverings when putting them on or removing them. (see âWhat is the correct way to wear a face mask or covering?â on this page for more details).

questionOriginal: How can I be safe from COVID-19 infection and prevent an overdose?
questionText: How can I be safe from COVID-19 infection and prevent an overdose?
answerOriginal:
Substance use may increase the risk of becoming seriously ill or dying from COVID-19, but more evidence is needed. At the same time, an opioid overdose is an immediate risk to your life. Know that stimulants may also have fentanyl in them, an opioid. Below are some tips to help avoid an overdose or be better prepared if one happens and to reduce your risk of getting COVID-19.

If you are alone:

  • Call, text or send a Facebook or other type of message to someone you trust. Tell them youâre going to use and make a safety plan. For example, ask them to call you in a certain number of minutes. If they donât hear from you, they should follow your plan. This could include coming over to check on you, calling a family member to check on you, or calling 911.
  • Call Never Use Alone at 800-484-3731 or message them on Facebook. Theyâll wait while you use and call for emergency services if you donât respond after a certain period of time.
  • Have Naloxone with you. Put it where someone checking on you will easily see it.
  • Wash your hands or use hand sanitizer.

If youâre not alone:

  • Try to keep a 6-foot distance from the other people youâre with, unless you live with them. People who live in the same household donât need to stay 6 feet apart.
  • Anyone in the room should wear a face mask or covering if they are not using and not part of your household.
  • Make sure someone you trust has naloxone on hand, and they arenât using at the moment.
  • Let them know when you are using so they can check in and give naloxone if needed.
  • Wash your hands or use hand sanitizer.

Whenever and wherever you use, these tips can help prevent an overdose:

  • Use one drug at a time (donât mix).
  • Know your tolerance. Use less if you havenât used in a while, or if youâve been sick, lost weight, or if something else has lowered your tolerance.
  • Test for fentanyl or assume there is fentanyl in your supply.
  • Start low and go slow. You can use more later.
  • Use in a lower risk way, like snorting instead of injecting or smoking.
  • Consider getting on medication assisted treatment (methadone, bupe, suboxone, etc.).
  • Call 802-565-LINK or go to VTHelplink to find a treatment center.

About wearing face masks or coverings:

Wearing a mask reduces the risk of transmission of COVID-19. However, substance use can impact your breathing and wearing a mask can make it worse. Plus, if you canât take your own mask off (like if youâre nodding out), you shouldnât wear one. When using substances with other people, particularly opioids, you may choose to stay 6 feet apart and not wear masks.

More information:

  • Tips to prevent an opioid overdose (Harm Reduction Coalition)
  • Helping during an overdose and finding Naloxone (Health Department)
  • Guidance for People Who Use Substances on COVID-19 (Yale)
  • Safer Drug Use During the COVID-19 Outbreak (Harm Reduction Coalition)

questionOriginal: What types of disinfectants should I be using to clean?
questionText: What types of disinfectants should I be using to clean?
answerOriginal:
Read the CDC's cleaning and disinfecting your home guidance.

Make sure you are using cleaning products and disinfectants safely. Follow these guidelines:

  • Follow the directions on the label

  • Donât mix chemicals

  • Wear protective gear (such as gloves)

  • Use them in a well-ventilated area

  • Store them out of reach of children

If you feel sick after using disinfectants, you can chat with the New England Poison Control Center on their website, call 1-800-222-1222 or text POISON to 85511.
answerText:
Find tips from the CDC on how toÂ clean and disinfect your home routinely and when someone is sick.
Make sure you are using cleaning products and disinfectants safely. Follow these guidelines:

Wear protective gear (such as gloves and eye protection)
Use them in a well-ventilated area
Follow the directions on the label
Use no more than the amount recommended on the label
Use water at room temperature for dilution (unless the label says a different temperature)
Donât mix chemicals
Label diluted cleaning products
Store them out of reach of children and pets

You should never eat, drink, breathe or inject these products into your body or apply directly to your skin as they can cause serious harm. Do not wipe or bathe pets with these products or any other products that are not approved for animal use.
If you feel sick after using disinfectants, you can chat with the New England Poison Control Center on their website, call 1-800-222-1222 or text POISON to 85511.

questionOriginal: Iâm a health professional and would like to volunteer. How do I get a temporary license?
questionText: Iâm a health professional and would like to volunteer. How do I get a temporary license?
answerOriginal:
Health care professionals can quickly become temporarily licensed to provide care during the COVID-19 public health emergency. This includes people who were previously licensed, even if they are retired from practice and do not hold an active license in any state.

The new emergency measures grant a temporary license for health professionals who:

  • Are licensed and in good standing in other states
  • Were licensed in Vermont, but whose licenses lapsed in recent years

There are no fees of any kind to obtain a temporary emergency license.

The process for applying will depend on the applicantâs status. Some just need to submit information about who they are and where they will be practicing. Others will be required to apply for the license using a streamlined process.

To apply for a license or get more information about the process contact the licensing authority for your profession:

  • Board of Medical Practice (medical doctors, physician assistants, and podiatrists) or 802-657-4223.
  • Office of Professional Regulation (other health care professions â including nurses and osteopathic physicians) or 802-828-1505.
answerText:
If you are a health care professional, you can quickly become temporarily licensed to provide care during the COVID-19 pandemic. You can be granted a temporary license if you:

Are licensed and in good standing in other states
Were licensed in Vermont, but your license lapsed in recent years

There are no fees of any kind to obtain a temporary emergency license.
To apply for a license or get more information about the process, contact the licensing authority for your profession:

Board of Medical Practice (medical doctors, physician assistants, and podiatrists) or 802-657-4223.
Office of Professional Regulation (other health care professions â including nurses and osteopathic physicians) or 802-828-1505.

questionOriginal: What does âinfectious periodâ mean?
questionText: What does âinfectious periodâ mean?
answerOriginal:
The infectious period is the period of time when someone with COVID-19 has a high chance of spreading the virus to others. The infectious period starts two days before any symptoms began â or for people with COVID-19 who don't have symptoms, two days before they got tested â and continues until they have recovered.

People who had close interactions with the person with COVID-19 during this time are at risk and may be considered close contacts.

People who had close interactions with the person with COVID-19 during this time are at risk and may be considered close contacts.

questionOriginal: Is there a medicine I can take to prevent or treat COVID-19?
questionText: Is there a medicine I can take to prevent or treat COVID-19?
answerOriginal:
As reports appear in the news of certain drugs being potentially used for treatment or prevention of COVID-19, the Vermont Department of Health strongly urges caution.

Though the anti-malarial drugs chloroquine and hydroxychloroquine, among others, have been widely discussed as potential treatments, the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention has said there are no data currently available from randomized clinical trials that would inform how these drugs could be used to treat COVID-19.

In fact, there are significant potential risks to taking such drugs, including death.

Health officials remind Vermonters that most people who get COVID-19 can manage their symptoms at home with rest, drinking fluids and taking fever-reducing medication. Talk to your health care provider before taking any substance alleged to prevent or treat COVID-19.

Providers should only prescribe these drugs for individuals with diagnosed conditions, and not for prevention, to help maintain the supply for Vermonters who need them.
answerText:
There are no drugs or other therapeutics currently approved to prevent or treat COVID-19. Most people who get COVID-19 can manage their symptoms at home with rest, drinking fluids and taking fever-reducing medication.
Scientists are working to develop effective treatments.
Though the anti-malarial drugs chloroquine and hydroxychloroquine, among others, have been widely discussed as potential treatments, the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention has said there are no data currently available that show how these drugs could be used to treat COVID-19. In fact, there are significant potential risks to taking such drugs, including death.
Talk to your health care provider before taking any substance alleged to prevent or treat COVID-19.
Providers should only prescribe these drugs for individuals with diagnosed conditions, and not for prevention, to help maintain the supply for Vermonters who need them.

questionOriginal: When can a person return to work if they have a symptom or multiple symptoms of COVID-19?
questionText: When can a person return to work if they have a symptom or multiple symptoms of COVID-19?
answerOriginal:
If you are sick with any symptoms of COVID-19,

Talk with your health care provider to determine if:

  • your symptoms are due to COVID-19 or some other reason
  • you should or should not go to public places or work

If COVID-19 is suspected, your health care provider can refer you for testing. Stay home while you are waiting for your test results. If you test positive, a Health Department contact tracer will reach out to walk you through what to do next.

You will be advised to stay home from work and other activities until:

  • fever has resolved for at least 24 hours without the use of fever-reducing medications, and other symptoms (like cough or shortness of breath) have improved â AND â
  • at least 10 days have passed since symptoms first appeared.

If you are sick due to something other than COVID-19, you should stay out of work until:

  • you have been without fever for 24 hours without using fever-reducing medications (if you had a fever) â AND â
  • any other symptoms have resolved or are improving.

your symptoms are due to COVID-19 or some other reason
you should or should not go to public places or work

fever has resolved for at least 24 hours without the use of fever-reducing medications, and other symptoms (like cough or shortness of breath) have improved â AND â

questionOriginal: How does being indoors with the windows closed affect my risk of getting COVID-19?
questionText: How does being indoors with the windows closed affect my risk of getting COVID-19?
answerOriginal:
Because of the nature of how the virus spreads and how it survives, being indoors increases your risk of spreading the COVID-19 virus and becoming infected with it.

The virus that causes COVID-19 is thought to spread mainly through close contact from person to person, by respiratory droplets when people with COVID-19 cough, sneeze, sing, talk, or breathe.

It is possible for COVID-19 to be transmitted under certain circumstances when very small respiratory droplets remain airborne. These small particles can infect someone who is more than 6 feet away. This airborne transmission is uncommon, but can happen when inside a building without proper ventilation that has allowed a buildup of respiratory droplets or particles.

In general, the more people there are in an indoor environment, the more there is a need for ventilation with outdoor air.

There is going to be some level of risk if you are indoors with people you donât live with. The level of risk can depend on multiple things, including:

  • How big the space is â Larger rooms or areas that allow enough space for everyone to keep a 6-foot distance from others are less of a risk than small rooms or areas that can easily get crowded.
  • How many people are in the room or area â A small number of people reduces your risk compared to many people who are not able to keep a 6-foot distance from others.
  • How much ventilation there is â Open windows and doors for ventilation with outdoor air. If it is too cold outside to open windows, then setting up a fan to pull air out of the room can reduce your risk. However, using a fan to blow air into or around the room or using ceiling fans is not recommended since they could keep the virus in the air for longer.
  • How humid the room or area is - Coronaviruses thrive when the relative humidity is below 40%, which usually happens when buildings are heated during the fall and winter. If you can, run a humidifier to maintain a relative humidity of at least 40% in the room or area where people are gathering.
  • What the people are doing in the room or area â Places where people can continuously wear a mask (for example, a family gathering without food or drink or a library) are less of a risk than places where people might take their masks off (for example, dinner at a friendâs house or a restaurant).

Be sure to take these general precautions any time you are in an indoor environment, whether you are at home or in another building:

  • Stay home if you are sick.
  • Avoid crowded indoor spaces.
  • Wear a face mask or covering.
  • Keep a 6-foot distance from people you donât live with.
  • Wash your hands often.

Learn more:

  • How to increase ventilation in your home from the EPA
  • FAQs about indoor air and COVID-19 from the EPA
  • Hosting gatherings or cook-outs from the CDC
  • Attending an event or gathering from the CDC
  • Holiday celebrations from the CDC

questionOriginal: How long can the virus live on surfaces?
questionText: How long can the virus live on surfaces?
answerOriginal:
Current evidence suggests that the COVID-19 virus may live for hours to days on surfaces made from a variety of materials, according to the CDC. It may be possible that a person can get COVID-19 by touching a surface or an object that has the virus on it and then touching their own mouth, nose, or possibly their eyes. However, this is not thought to be the main way the virus spreads. The virus is thought to spread mainly from person-to-person.

Cleaning and disinfecting frequently touched surfaces daily are the best ways to help stop the spread of the COVID-19 virus in households and community settings.

Read the CDC's cleaning and disinfection for households guidance for more information.
answerText:
It is possible that a person could get COVID-19 by touching a surface or object that has the virus on it and then touching their own mouth, nose, or eyes, but this is not thought to be a common way that COVID-19 spreads. This can be prevented by washing your hands before you touch your face, mouth or eyes. The virus is thought to spread mainly through close contact from person to person.
If someone is sick with COVID-19, you should regularly clean and disinfect frequently touched surfaces (for example, tables, countertops, doorknobs, light switches, toilets, faucet handles and sinks). Follow the steps for how to clean and disinfect your home from the CDC.

questionOriginal: Is it safe to wear gaiters instead of masks?
questionText: Is it safe to wear gaiters instead of masks?
answerOriginal:
Generally, we recommend face masks and coverings that are made of at least two layers. Materials with tighter weaves, like cotton T-shirt material, are better at trapping respiratory droplets and preventing the spread of the COVID-19 virus than materials with loose weaves, like gaiters.

If you choose to wear a gaiter as a face covering, fold it over so it is two layers. Based on a few experiments in adults, gaiters with one layer trap the least amount of respiratory droplets. Gaiters with two layers trap more droplets than gaiters with one layer. Gaiters folded over into two layers have a similar effectiveness at trapping respiratory droplets as two layers of cotton T-shirt material.
answerText:
Generally, we recommend face masks and coverings that are made of at least two layers. Materials with tighter weaves, like cotton T-shirt material, are better at trapping respiratory droplets and preventing the spread of the COVID-19 virus than materials with loose weaves, like gaiters.
If you choose to wear a gaiter as a face covering, fold it over so it is two layers. Based on a few experiments in adults, gaiters with one layer trap the least amount of respiratory droplets. Gaiters with two layers trap more droplets than gaiters with one layer. Gaiters folded over into two layers have a similar effectiveness at trapping respiratory droplets as two layers of cotton T-shirt material.

questionOriginal: How does COVID-19 spread?
questionText: How does COVID-19 spread?
answerOriginal:
The virus is thought to spread mainly from person-to-person.

  • Between people who are in close contact with one another (within about 6 feet).

  • Through respiratory droplets produced when an infected person coughs, sneezes or talks.

  • These droplets can land in the mouths or noses of people who are nearby or possibly be inhaled into the lungs.

  • Some recent studies have suggested that COVID-19 may be spread by people who are not showing symptoms.

It may be possible that a person can get COVID-19 by touching a surface or object that has the virus on it and then touching their own mouth, nose, or possibly their eyes, but this is not thought to be the main way the virus spreads.

Learn from the CDC how to help prevent spread of the virus and how to protect yourself and others from getting sick.
answerText:
COVID-19 most commonly spreads during close contact through respiratory droplets
COVID-19 is thought to spread mainly through close contact from person to person, including between people who are near each other (within about 6 feet).
When people with COVID-19 cough, sneeze, sing, talk, or breathe they produce respiratory droplets. Another person can become infected if they inhale the droplets, or if droplets land in their nose or mouth.
COVID-19 can sometimes spread through airborne transmission
As the respiratory droplets travel further from the person with COVID-19, the concentration of these droplets decreases. Larger droplets fall out of the air due to gravity. Smaller droplets and particles spread apart in the air.
It is possible for COVID-19 to be transmitted under certain circumstances when very small respiratory droplets remain airborne. These small particles can infect someone who is more than 6 feet away.
This airborne transmission is uncommon, but has occurred in situations such as indoors when a person with COVID-19 had symptoms and been coughing for longer than 30 minutes. Other examples include shouting, singing or exercising, or being in a building without proper ventilation that allowed a buildup of respiratory droplets or particles.
COVID-19 spreads less commonly through contact with contaminated surfaces
Respiratory droplets can also land on surfaces and objects. It is possible that a person could get COVID-19 by touching a surface or object that has the virus on it and then touching their own mouth, nose, or eyes, but this is not thought to be a common way that COVID-19 spreads. This can be prevented by washing your hands before you touch your face, mouth or eyes.
Not everyone infected with the virus has symptoms.
Follow these general precautions to help prevent the virus from spreading:

Keep a 6-foot distance from people you donât live with.
Wear a face mask or covering when you canât keep 6 feet apart.
Avoid crowded indoor spaces.
Wash your hands often.
Stay home if you are sick.

Learn more from the CDC about how to protect yourself and others from getting sick.

questionOriginal: Is there any financial assistance available?
questionText: Is there any financial assistance available?
answerOriginal:
The Agency of Commerce and Community Development (ACCD) has answers to questions regarding financial assistance (for example, mortgage, utility bills, internet, and taxes) and housing (for example, paying rent, short-term housing and emergency housing) on its COVID-19 Resource Recovery Center.

Housing assistance programs for those affected by COVID-19 are available. Find information on rental assistance and mortgage assistance.
answerText:

questionOriginal: Is there temporary housing available if I might have or have tested positive for COVID-19?

questionOriginal: How can we safely carpool?
questionText: How can we safely carpool?
answerOriginal:
If possible, donât carpool. This is because people will be within 6 feet of each other and in an enclosed space. If you need to carpool to work, school or sports games or practices, itâs best to:

  • Wear masks at all times.
  • Limit the number of people you carpool with.
  • Carpool with the same people, ideally those who are following the COVID-19 prevention steps in their day-to-day lives.
  • Keep a log of who you and your family have carpooled with that includes dates, names of other riders, and the duration of the ride.
  • Keep the windows or vents open for fresh air.
  • Cover your coughs and sneezes.
  • Clean and disinfect surfaces often.
  • Wash or sanitize your hands before getting in and out of the car.

Do not carpool if you are sick or have been in close contact with someone who has tested positive for COVID-19.

Read the CDCâs tips on carpooling safely.

questionOriginal: Does smoking or vaping increase the risk of getting seriously ill from COVID-19?
questionText: Does smoking or vaping increase the risk of getting seriously ill from COVID-19?
answerOriginal:
There is growing evidence that e-cigarette use or vaping can harm lung health. The coronavirus attacks the lungs, making it harder for people who smoke or vape â tobacco, cannabis or anything else â to fight off the virus, putting them at much greater risk of severe illness, even death.

802Quits is the Vermont tobacco quit resource. You can get help to quit by phone or online.

By phone, call 1-800-QUIT-NOW for 1:1 coaching, available 24/7, with email and text support.

Online: 802Quits.org

By quitting, youâll also protect people in your household by reducing their exposure to secondhand smoke and aerosol as you spend more time at home right now.
answerText:
People who smoke â tobacco, cannabis or anything else â have an increased risk of severe illness from COVID-19, a disease that attacks the lungs. Vaping damages your lungsâ immune system and is linked to a substantially increased risk of COVID-19 among teenagers and young adults.
802Quits is Vermontâs tobacco quit resource. Help is available online and by phone for Vermonters 13 and older. Call 1-800-QUIT-NOW for one-on-one coaching, available 24/7, with free nicotine replacement therapy, email and text support, or visit 802quits.org for online workshops and customized quit tools.
My Life, My Quit is a free, confidential quit program designed for teens, available by texting âStart My Quitâ to 855-891-9989 or calling to talk with a coach.
By quitting, youâll also protect people in your household by reducing their exposure to the dangerous chemicals in secondhand smoke and aerosol as you spend more time at home during the pandemic.

questionOriginal: What are some ways I can talk about my COVID-19 "comfort level" when making plans with friends and family?
questionText: What are some ways I can talk about my COVID-19 "comfort level" when making plans with friends and family?
answerOriginal:
As life picks up again, we are learning there is a lot to discuss before seeing friends and family to feel comfortable and stay safe. Here are four tips to help have the âCOVID Talkâ â a conversation to negotiate boundaries and establish expectations ahead of time.

  1. Ask questions. Before you get together, start with an open and honest conversation about what everyone has been doing to stay healthy and how they have been socializing. Consider everyoneâs worries, boundaries and possible COVID-19 exposure risk so you can all get on the same page.
  2. Focus on what you need. Using âIâ instead of âyouâ statements helps people avoid feeling defensive or judged. In fact, blaming and shaming may actually increase push back and the likelihood of risk-taking behaviors. We recommend sharing what youâre comfortable with based on your own perspective instead of making demands of others.
  3. Share why it is important to you. Share what level of risk works for you and why. It might be different for others. Some people feel comfortable taking on a moderate amount of risk in their lives. Others may not feel comfortable taking on any risk. Focusing on your own reasons for staying safe can help people to better understand and get on board.
  4. Set boundaries and stick to them. We are all for keeping it friendly, open and non-judgmental â but that doesnât mean you have to skimp on your safety! Itâs OK to be clear and straightforward with what you need to feel safe and comfortable. Itâs also okay to decline invitations or leave situations that feel too risky. You should never have to feel bad or apologize for prioritizing your safety. Lead by example by sticking to what works for you and avoiding judgment.

Find some examples of the âCOVID Talkâ.

questionOriginal: What should dentists know about COVID-19?
questionText: What should dentists know about COVID-19?
answerOriginal:
On April 27, a dental health care referral network for emergency dental procedures was set up. Read the April 27 Health Alert.

On April 10, Governor Phil Scott extended his order of dental health care professionals practicing in Vermont to suspend all elective dental care until May 15, 2020. This order applies to both children and adult patients. Read Addendum 9 to the Executive Order for more information.

Health care professionals must continue to be available to their patients as needed for emergencies and urgent care.

Read the March 23 Health Alert as it pertains to emergency and elective dental care in light of COVID-19, the rationale for this action, including definitions of what constitutes a dental emergency and conditions requiring urgent care.

Find more information for health care professionals.
answerText:
The challenge with dentistry is the generation of aerosols as part of many office-based activities. This includes dental hygiene through a variety of preventive, restorative, endodontic, periodontic and orthodontic procedures.
Dental health care professionals can resume all procedures, including those that generate aerosol. Read the Interim Guidance for Resuming Dental Services in Vermont.
Dentists and other health care providers must continue to be available to their patients as needed for emergencies and urgent care.
Find more information for health care professionals.

questionOriginal: What is isolation, quarantine and self-observation?
questionText: What is isolation, quarantine and self-observation?
answerOriginal:
• Isolation is for people who are sick with COVID-19.

  • Quarantine is for people with no symptoms and who were in close contact with someone sick with COVID-19 or are returning to Vermont from out of state for anything other than an essential purpose.

  • Self-observation is for other Vermonters who donât have symptoms of COVID-19.

For more information, see the What is isolation, quarantine and self-observation? chart.
answerText:
Isolation is when people with COVID-19 stay home, and away from other people, until they have recovered, to prevent further spread. Learn about the timeline for people with COVID-19 (with symptoms and without symptoms) from being exposed to being released from isolation.
If you test positive for COVID-19, the Health Department's team of expert contact tracers will call you to provide guidance and information on staying home. They will also ask you about your close contacts. Contact tracers call your close contacts to make sure they know to stay home and quarantine to prevent further spread. Learn more about the timeline for close contacts, from when they have may have been exposed, to when they can end quarantine.
Learn more about isolation, quarantine and self-observation and what to do if you have COVID-19.

questionOriginal: What should I do if I feel sick and think I may have COVID-19?
questionText: What should I do if I feel sick and think I may have COVID-19?
answerOriginal:
If you are having symptoms of COVID-19, call your health care provider to find out if you should be tested.

Follow these guidelines to help keep others from getting sick:

Isolate at home:

  • Donât leave home, except to get medical care. Call ahead before visiting a health care provider or emergency department. Wear a cloth face mask or covering if you need to leave home for medical care

  • Most people with mild illness can recover at home. While there is no specific treatment for COVID-19, you should get plenty of rest, drink plenty of fluids, and take fever-reducing medication if needed.

  • Stay in a specific room in your home and use a separate bathroom, as much as possible. Stay at least 6 feet away from others in your home at all times and wear a cloth face mask or covering if you are in the same room with them. Donât share household items.

  • Have someone else care for your pets. There have been a small number of pets, including cats and dogs, reported to be infected with the COVID-19 virus, mostly after close contact with people with COVID-19. If you must care for your pet, wear a cloth face mask or covering, and wash your hands before and after.

Daily cleaning and washing:

  • Clean and disinfect surfaces in your separate room and bathroom. Have someone else clean the other areas of your home.

  • Thoroughly wash household items, like utensils, after using.

  • Wash your hands often with soap and water for at least 20 seconds. Use alcohol-based hand sanitizer with at least 60% alcohol if soap and water arenât available.

Find out what to do if you are diagnosed with COVID-19.

For more information, see CDC's guidance on what to do if you are sick.
answerText:
If you are having symptoms of COVID-19, call your health care provider to find out if you should be tested. If you do not have a health care provider, call 2-1-1 to be connected to care, or contact the nearest federally qualified health center or one of Vermontâs free & referral clinics.
If you or a family member are sick, follow these steps to care for yourself and to help protect other people in your home and your community:

Stay home except to get medical care.
Separate yourself from other people.
Monitor your symptoms.
Call ahead before visiting your doctor.
Wear a cloth face mask or covering when youâre around people and pets.
Cover your coughs and sneezes with your sleeve or a tissue, then throw the tissue in the trash.
Wash your hands often. Use an alcohol-based sanitizer if soap and water aren't available.
Avoid sharing personal household items.
Clean all high-touch surfaces in your home daily.

Find more details on what to do if you are sick from the CDC.
Find out what to do if you are diagnosed with COVID-19.

There are also more frequently asked questions about the data above the dashboard.

questionOriginal: How many people who have tested positive for COVID-19 are in my town or county?
questionText: How many people who have tested positive for COVID-19 are in my town or county?
answerOriginal:
You can find the number of people who have tested positive for COVID-19 by county on the Current Activity in Vermont data dashboard. This map is updated daily.

There is also a map showing the number of Vermonters who have tested positive for COVID-19 by the town where they live. Residents of long-term care facilities and inmates at correctional facilities are included in the town of their facility when they were tested. This map is updated weekly.

The Health Department shares information for towns as a number range. This is to protect the privacy of people who have tested positive for COVID-19. If some information is made public (for example, gender, age, race, health condition, travel history), then a person could be identified, especially if the population of a town is small. This follows both federal and Vermont laws.

The COVID-19 virus is spreading throughout Vermont, and many people may have it and can spread it for up to two days before they show symptoms. It is safe to assume that the virus is in your town or community, and you should take steps to protect yourself and others.

A Weekly Summary of Vermont COVID-19 Data is also available that includes more details on who has been impacted by COVID-19 in Vermont. You can find out more about testing trends, outbreaks, pre-existing conditions and symptoms of Vermonters with COVID-19.
answerText:
The number of people who have tested positive for COVID-19 by county is updated daily on the Vermont Dashboard.
The number of Vermonters who have tested positive for COVID-19 by the town where they live is updated weekly on the map of cases by town.
When looking at the county or town numbers, please remember that low or no recent cases is not the same as âsafer.â We know the virus is in our communities, and we should continue to follow health guidance to slow the spread of COVID-19 â no matter where we live in or visit. The maps reflect the number of people who had a positive test. There may be people in your county or town that have COVID-19 but have not been tested.
Weekly Data Summaries include more details on who has been impacted by COVID-19 in Vermont. You can find out more about testing trends, outbreaks, pre-existing conditions and symptoms of Vermonters with COVID-19.

questionOriginal: What does close contact mean?
questionText: What does close contact mean?
answerOriginal:
Close contact means being within 6 feet, for a long time, of someone who has tested positive for COVID-19 during their infectious period, which starts two days (48 hours) before any symptoms began and continues until they are recovered. Close contact does not mean being more than 6 feet away in the same indoor environment for a long period of time, walking by, or briefly being in the same room with someone.

A âlong period of timeâ is hard to define because it depends on whether the person was sick at the time and what type of interaction you had with that person. These examples can help you determine whether you were a close contact or not.

Examples of close contacts:

  • You live in the same home.

  • You are intimate partners.

  • You rode in the same car while the person was infectious.

  • You had dinner together while the person was infectious.

Examples of not close contacts:

  • You were their cashier at the grocery store.

  • You are a pharmacist who gave the person medication.

  • You were in front of the person in line at the store.

  • You are a coworker who briefly walked by to ask a question.

A team at the Health Department works with people with COVID-19 to identify their close contacts. This is called contact tracing. The team assesses each close contact for their exposure risk and gives them health guidance and recommendations for self-isolation or other restrictions.

As the state reopens, Vermonters should consider keeping a contact journal â a list of other people who you have been in close contact with each day. If you do get sick, this would make it easier to get in touch with those people and so they can take proper precautions to prevent further spread of COVID-19.

The chart describing what is isolation, quarantine and self-observation has details about what you should do and not do, depending on your exposure risk.

Find out more about what to do if you are a close contact of someone who is diagnosed with COVID-19.
answerText:
Close contact means being within 6 feet, for a total of 15 minutes or more over a 24-hour period, of someone who has tested positive for COVID-19 during their infectious period. The infectious period starts two days before any symptoms began â or for people with COVID-19 who don't have symptoms, two days before they got tested â and continues until they are recovered.
Close contact does not mean being more than 6 feet away in the same indoor environment for a short period of time, walking by, or briefly being in the same room with someone.
Here are some examples:
Examples of close contacts:

You live in the same home.
You are intimate partners.
You rode in the same car while the person was infectious.
You had dinner together while the person was infectious.

Examples of not close contacts:

You were their cashier at the grocery store.
You were their server at a restaurant.
You are a pharmacist who gave the person medication.
You were in front of the person in line at the store.
You are a coworker who briefly walked by to ask a question.

If you are identified as a close contact,Â you will be contacted. The notification could come from the Health Department, your employer, school, or health care provider, for example.Â TheyÂ will call you and tell you the date when you may have been exposed. They will give you guidance to stay home and away from others for a certain amount of time. They will ask you to watch for symptoms and ask if you need any help while staying home. Learn how contact tracing for COVID-19 works in Vermont.
Consider keeping a contact journal â a list of other people who you have been in close contact with each day. If you do get sick, this would make it easier to get in touch with those people and so they can take proper precautions to prevent further spread of COVID-19.

questionOriginal: Do I need to quarantine if someone I live with is waiting for their COVID-19 test results?
questionText: Do I need to quarantine if someone I live with is waiting for their COVID-19 test results?
answerOriginal:
You do not need to quarantine if you live with someone who is waiting for their test results only if you:

  • do not have symptoms of COVID-19.
  • have not had contact with someone who has tested positive for COVID-19.
  • have not traveled out of Vermont for the past 14 days.

This means that you can go to school, work, or the grocery store.

Be sure to stay at least 6 feet from the person who is under quarantine. People who are under quarantine should wear a mask in common spaces, use a separate bathroom, eat separately, and otherwise not be in close contact with others in the household who are not under quarantine. Be sure to disinfect commonly touched surfaces, and check yourself for symptoms for 14 days.

If you have symptoms of COVID-19, talk with your health care provider. If you don't have a provider, call 2-1-1 to be connected to care, or contact the nearestÂ federally qualified health centerÂ or one ofÂ Vermont's free & referral clinics.

questionOriginal: What is an outbreak of COVID-19?
questionText: What is an outbreak of COVID-19?
answerOriginal:
Outbreaks have different definitions depending on the setting in which they occur, including community, educational, congregate living or workplace settings. They can be two or more cases that are epidemiologically connected.

Learn more about what an outbreak means, when they are considered resolved, how many have happened in each type of setting, plus find more data on outbreaks that have happened in Vermont in our Weekly Data Summary.
answerText:
The Health Department refers to âsituationsâ when one person who tested positive for COVID-19 was at a setting (for example, at school, their work place, or a health care facility) or an event (for example, a private party) while they were infectious and there is a concern that the virus could spread to others who attended the event or who were present at the setting. Situations usually require more follow up than only notifying close contacts. The Health Department monitors situations but does not report any data on them.
However, a situation may become an outbreak. An outbreak means that the virus has spread to more than one person associated with the setting or the event. Learn more about what an outbreak means, when they are considered resolved, how many have happened in each type of setting, plus find more data on outbreaks that have happened in Vermont in our Weekly Data Summary.

questionOriginal: What if there is a case of COVID-19 in school?
questionText: What if there is a case of COVID-19 in school?
answerOriginal:
The Health Department quickly responds every time we receive a positive test result for COVID-19. A contact tracer calls the person who tested positive (or their parent) within 24 hours, asks them questions about their recent activities and who theyâve been in contact with during their infectious period, and gives instructions on staying home. The team contacts the school if the person was there while infectious. Schools do not need to take action if someone with COVID-19 was not at the school during their infectious period.

The Health Department will:

  • Work closely with the school and ask about who had close contact (within 6 feet for at least 15 minutes) with the person with COVID-19 while they were infectious, like classmates and teachers. Information that identifies the individual will only be shared if consent was given.
  • Reach out to all people with close contact and give them information about quarantine and testing.
  • Discuss next steps with school administration, including whether to temporarily move to remote instruction.

The school will:

  • Close off any areas where the person spent longer than 15 minutes (like a classroom, gym, or a cafeteria) then clean and disinfect the areas.
  • Communicate with parents and staff about the situation, and encourage everyone to answer calls from the Health Department for contact tracing, if they get called. Contact tracers only call the people who our infectious disease experts determine have had close contact with a person with COVID-19 while they were infectious.
  • Clean and disinfect frequently touched surfaces in the school.
  • Make sure that anyone who tests positive for COVID-19 stays home from school (isolation) until they can return.
  • Make sure that anyone who had close contact with someone with COVID-19 while they were infectious stays home from school (quarantine) until they can return. Someone under quarantine does not have COVID-19 and cannot pass it to others, but they may become infected within 14 days.

Learn more about the Health Department's response to COVID-19 cases.

Several resources for school administrators, nurses and COVID coordinators are available on the Health Department School web page including a quick reference guide for when someone with COVID-19 was at school while infectious.

You can learn more about that and other information about what parents can expect for pre-K through 12th grade as schools reopen for the fall.
answerText:
The Health Department quickly responds every time we receive a positive test result for COVID-19. Schools are encouraged to call the Health Department when learning of a positive test result.
The Health Department will:

Contact the person who tested positive (or their parent/guardian), ask them questions about their recent activities and who theyâve been in close contact with, and give instructions on staying home.
Notify the school if the person who tested positive is associated with a school.
Schools do not need to take action if the Health Department determines that there is no risk of further spread at the school. For example, if the person with COVID-19 was not at school during their infectious period, there would not have been an opportunity to spread the virus to others at school.
Work closely with the school to identify close contacts at school (within 6 feet for a total of 15 minutes or more over a 24-hour period) of the person who tested positive with COVID-19 during their infectious period.
Discuss next steps with school administration, including whether to temporarily close the classroom for in-person instruction. These decisions are made on a case by case basis. The Health Department will provide guidance based on a number of factors, including the level of community transmission, the number of students or staff infected, the status of contact tracing, the number of days the infectious person was at school, infection control policies and practices, the number and structure of classes, pods, or grades affected, and other opportunities for transmission, like extra-curricular activities.

The school will:

Close off any areas where the person spent longer than 15 minutes (like a classroom, gym, or a cafeteria) then clean and disinfect the areas.
Communicate with parents and staff about the situation.
Support the Health Departmentâs efforts by notifying people associated with the school who have been identified as close contacts. The school will provide them with Health Department guidance and information on quarantine and testing. Quarantine means staying home and away from other people for up to 14 days.
Make sure that anyone who tests positive for COVID-19 stays home from school (isolation) until they can return. Find out what to do if you test positive for COVID-19.
Make sure that anyone who had close contact with someone with COVID-19 while they were infectious stays home from school (quarantine) until they can return. Find out what to do if you are a close contact.

For more information:

Learn more about theÂ Health Department's response to COVID-19 cases.

questionOriginal: I am in quarantine, but I canât avoid close contact with someone I take care of. Do they need to quarantine?
questionText: I am in quarantine, but I canât avoid close contact with someone I take care of. Do they need to quarantine?
answerOriginal:
In situations where close contact cannot be avoided, close contacts of the person under quarantine do not also need to quarantine. For example, if a person depends on someone who is under quarantine for care and basic needs, and close contact cannot be avoided, the person who receives care may continue with activities outside of the home. For example, they may continue to go to work, school, child care, the grocery store, etc.

As much as possible, continue to practice these prevention steps. Stay at least 6 feet from the person who is under quarantine. People who are under quarantine should wear a mask in common spaces, use a separate bathroom, eat separately, and otherwise not be in close contact with others in the household who are not under quarantine. Be sure to disinfect commonly touched surfaces, and check yourself for symptoms for 14 days.

Quarantine is used to keep someone who might have been exposed to COVID-19 away from others to prevent further spread. Quarantine means staying at a home or dwelling for 14 days since the day they were potentially exposed, before doing any activities outside of the home. People in quarantine should separate themselves from others and check themselves for symptoms.

questionOriginal: What are the long-term health effects of COVID-19?
questionText: What are the long-term health effects of COVID-19?
answerOriginal:
The CDC is working to learn more about the whole range of short- and long-term health effects associated with COVID-19. Many organs besides the lungs are affected by COVID-19, and there are many ways the infection can affect someoneâs health.

One of the health effects that the CDC is closely watching and working to understand relates to COVID-19 and the heart. Heart conditions associated with COVID-19 include inflammation and damage to the heart muscle itself, known as myocarditis, or inflammation of the covering of the heart, known as pericarditis. These conditions can occur by themselves or in combination. Heart damage may be an important part of severe disease and death from COVID-19, especially in older people with underlying illnesses. Heart damage like this might also explain some frequently reported long-term symptoms like shortness of breath, chest pain, and heart palpitations.

The risk of heart damage may not be limited to older and middle-aged adults. For example, young adults with COVID-19, including athletes, can also suffer from myocarditis. Severe heart damage has occurred in young, healthy people, but is rare. There may be more cases of mild effects of COVID-19 on the heart that can be diagnosed with special imaging tests, including in younger people with mild or minimal symptoms; however, the long-term significance of these mild effects on the heart are unknown. The CDC will continue to assess and provide updates as new data emerge.
answerText:
The CDC is working to learn more about the whole range of short- and long-term health effects associated with COVID-19. Many organs besides the lungs are affected by COVID-19, and there are many ways the infection can affect someoneâs health.
While most people with COVID-19 recover and return to normal health, some can have symptoms that can last for weeks or even months after their recovery. Even people who are not hospitalized and who have a mild illness can experience persistent or late symptoms. Studies are being done to learn more.
Find out what the long-term health symptoms and complications of COVID-19 are from the CDC.

questionText: I am in isolation because I tested positive for COVID-19, but I can't avoid close contact with someone I take care of. Do they need to quarantine?
answerOriginal: Yes. questionOriginal: How is a sample collected for COVID-19 testing?
questionText: How is a sample collected for COVID-19 testing?
answerOriginal:
Usually a health care provider collects samples (specimens) from you in one of two ways, but there are other options:

  1. The health care provider collects a nasal, or nasopharyngeal (NP) swab. This is when a dry swab is inserted through one nostril and is rubbed against the back of your nose and throat.
  2. The health care provider collects a sample from the front of your nose with a dry swab.
answerText:
Usually, samples (specimens) are collected from you in one of two ways:

Nasal swab - this is a short, dry swab that is used to collect a sample from the front of your nose. This type of test is used at the Health Departmentâs testing sites. It is also used for certain priority groups, including children.
Nasopharyngeal or NP swab â this is a long, dry swab that is inserted through one nostril and is rubbed against the back of your nose and throat.

questionOriginal: What information is available for long-term care facilities and other facilities that serve older Vermonters (group homes, nursing homes, assisted living, and state therapeutic care residences)?
questionText: What information is available for long-term care facilities and other facilities that serve older Vermonters (group homes, nursing homes, assisted living, and state therapeutic care residences)?
answerOriginal:
Starting June 19, facilities may offer limited visitation outside with residents. Check with the facility first before planning a visit.

Medically necessary personnel and visitors for residents receiving end-of-life care are allowed inside. Read the executive order.

The Health Department recommends that all health care personnel in long-term care facilities and other congregate settings where health care is provided wear face masks, regardless of the presence of COVID-19 in the facility.

Any new admissions to nursing homes, assisted living residences, and residential care homes must complete the full 14-day quarantine period first.

Senior Centers may reopen with guidance from the Health Department and the Department of Aging and Independent Living. Adult Day programs remain closed.

There is guidance Â­on preventing the spread of COVID-19 for managers and owners of senior living communities, which includes making a plan, preparing common spaces and communicating with residents/staff, in addition to outlining the role of the Health Department.

Find more guidance and information for long-term care and group living settings.

There is a table showing active outbreaks in long-term care facilities, which is updated on Tuesdays and Fridays.
The Health Department recommends surveillance testing at long-term care facilities to identify people with COVID-19 and to help stop outbreaks in long-term care facilities.

COVID-19 activity in the community may affect how facilities and providers make decisions about testing, operations and personal protective equipment (PPE). Find information for health care providers, nursing homes and other long-term care facilities to make decisions based on measures of community-level burden.

questionOriginal: What is Sara Alert?
questionText: What is Sara Alert?
answerOriginal:
Sara Alert is a free, automated and secure reminder system to check for common symptoms of COVID-19. People who have tested positive for COVID-19, their close contacts, and people traveling or returning to Vermont can quickly and easily sign up for to receive free daily reminders to check themselves for symptoms by email, text or phone call. If symptoms are reported, the Health Department will reach out to provide guidance and next steps. Sara Alert helps our public health teams contain the spread of COVID-19.

Please note, Sara Alert is not a contact tracing system. It is not GPS based, so it does not monitor your movements.

If you are traveling or returning to Vermont, you are strongly encouraged to sign up with Sara Alert once you arrive in Vermont to get two weeks of daily symptom check reminders.

Sign up for Sara Alert.
answerText:
Sara Alert is a free, automated and secure reminder system to check for common symptoms of COVID-19. Sara Alert is for:

People who test positive for COVID-19
Close contacts of people with COVID-19
People visiting or returning to Vermont

Once you sign up, Sara Alert sends daily reminders until they automatically stop after two weeks. You can choose to receive messages by email, text or phone. If you report symptoms, the Health Department will reach out to provide guidance and next steps.
Sara Alert is not a contact tracing system. It is not GPS-based, so it does not monitor your movements or track your location.
Here are some reasons why you should sign up for Sara Alert:

You get fast, easy, and free reminders to check yourself for symptoms.
You get quick access to the Health Department for guidance and information if you develop symptoms.
It helps our public health teams contain the spread of COVID-19.

If you are a close contact of someone who has COVID-19, you will be given the link to sign up for Sara Alert when you are notified.
If you are visiting Vermont or recently returned to Vermont, learn more about Sara Alert and sign up. Visitors or returning travelers who are currently enrolled in Sara Alert who have questions about their messages can email the Travel Team or call 802-863-7240 (option 6).
