questionOriginal: What do I do if I test positive for COVID-19?
questionText: What do I do if I test positive for COVID-19?
answerOriginal:
Most people with mild illness can recover at home. While there is no specific treatment for COVID-19, you should get plenty of rest, drink plenty of fluids, and take fever-reducing medication if needed.

If you or a family member are sick, follow these steps to care for yourself and to help protect other people in your home and your community:

Isolate at home

  • Stay home, except to get medical care. Call ahead before visiting your health care provider. Anyone who does not have a health care provider can call 2-1-1 to be connected to care or contact the nearest federally qualified health center or one of Vermont's free & referral clinics.
  • Separate yourself from other people and pets**.**
  • Monitor your symptoms.
  • Wear a face mask or covering when you're around people and pets.
  • Cover your coughs and sneezes with your sleeve or a tissue, then throw the tissue in the trash.
  • Wash your hands often. Use an alcohol-based sanitizer if soap and water aren't available.
  • Avoid sharing personal household items**.**
  • Clean all high-touch surfaces in your home daily.
  • Get support from others. Stay in touch with family and friends by phone, email or online platform.

Someone from the Health Department will contact you to ask for your help with contact tracing. Contact tracing is used to provide education, support and guidance to people who are diagnosed with an infectious disease. Itâs also used to identify people who have been in close contact with them, so they can take steps to stop the disease from spreading to others.

Learn more:

  • Caring for yourself at home from the CDC
  • 10 ways to manage respiratory symptoms at home from the CDC
  • Information on breastfeeding if you have COVID-19 from the CDC
  • What is isolation, quarantine and self-observation
  • What to do if you test positive for COVID-19
answerText:
You will need to isolate if you test positive for COVID-19. Isolation means you need to stay home and away from other people, until you have recovered. This is to prevent further spread of the virus. A contact tracer will call you to give you guidance. They will answer any questions you may have and see if you need help getting resources to stay home.
Most people with mild illness can recover at home. While there is no specific treatment for COVID-19, you should get plenty of rest, drink plenty of fluids, and take fever-reducing medication if needed.
If you or a family member are sick, follow these steps to care for yourself and to help protect other people in your home and your community:

Stay home, except to get medical care. Call ahead before visiting your health care provider. Anyone who does not have a health care provider can call 2-1-1 to be connected to care or contact the nearest federally qualified health center or one of Vermont's free & referral clinics.
Separate yourself from other people and pets.
Monitor your symptoms.
Wear a mask when you're around people and pets.
Cover your coughs and sneezes with your sleeve or a tissue. Then throw the tissue in the trash.
Wash your hands often. Use an alcohol-based sanitizer if soap and water aren't available.
Avoid sharing personal household items.
Clean all high-touch surfaces in your home daily.
Get support from others. Stay in touch with family and friends by phone, email or online platform.
Monitor your blood oxygen levels. People diagnosed with COVID-19 may have below-normal levels of oxygen in their blood before they feel short of breath. Finding low oxygen levels early can help you know to seek medical care sooner. This could make the disease less severe. Learn more about this program.

Learn more about what to do if you test positive for COVID-19.

questionOriginal: What does a "pending" test result mean?
questionText: What does a "pending" test result mean?
answerOriginal: "Pending" means that your test results are not yet ready. Test results will be available typically within 3 business days. Business days are Monday through Friday. If your test was more than 3 business days ago and your test result is still listed as pending, please call 802-863-7240 option 9.

questionOriginal: What is an antigen test?
questionText: What is an antigen test?
answerOriginal:
An antigen test is a newer type of COVID-19 test that identifies people who are currently infected with the COVID-19 virus.

Antigen tests provide results much more quickly than diagnostic, or PCR, tests (the most common type of test used to diagnose COVID-19 infection). But antigen tests may not be as accurate.

Antigen tests may be used to screen people to identify those who need a more definitive test.

We are monitoring how these antigen tests evolve and how results can best be used. Currently, people who test positive from antigen tests are not considered lab-confirmed cases and are not included in our total number of cases. However, we recommend they follow the same guidelines as a positive case to stay home (self-isolate). We would also conduct contact tracing and recommend a more accurate diagnostic test to confirm the positive result.

Antigen tests are different from antibody (serologic) tests, which identify people who have previously been infected with the coronavirus and do not show whether a person is currently infected.
answerText:
An antigen test for COVID-19 is a type of test that identifies people who are currently infected with the COVID-19 virus. Antigen tests provide results much more quickly than PCR tests (the most common type of test used to diagnose and confirm COVID-19 infection). Antigen tests are sometimes referred to as rapid (fast) tests.
Antigen tests are usually less sensitive than PCR tests, so they might miss some cases. Antigen tests could be more useful in certain circumstances:

For people who have symptoms of COVID-19. So far, studies on antigen tests have only been done on people with symptoms, and we do not have evidence about the accuracy of the antigen test on people without symptoms.
Health care providers may use antigen testing when PCR testing is not available or when results are needed quickly. This may be when people who are having symptoms get tested at their doctorâs office or when patients are being admitted to hospitals that donât have a lot of PCR tests available.
Antigen tests may be used to screen people to identify those who need a more definitive test. Antigen tests are particularly helpful when used to test people in the early stages of infection (within the first 5 to 7 days of having COVID-19 symptoms) when the viral load is generally the highest. For example, long-term care facilities could screen residents and staff who are not having symptoms, but only if the tests were done at least weekly.
For surveillance purposes, to see what COVID-19 activity might be occurring in a community.

When used to test people with COVID-19 symptoms, antigen tests have a higher chance of missing an active infection than PCR tests. This means that if you have symptoms, you may receive a negative result but still be infected with COVID-19.
Antigen tests are different from antibody (serologic) tests, which identify people who have previously been infected with the COVID-19 virus and do not show whether a person is currently infected.
Learn more:

Use of Antigen Testing in Vermont â Health Update October 1, 2020
Coronavirus testing basics from the Food and Drug Administration
Considerations for Implementation of SARS-CoV-2 Rapid Antigen Testing from the Association of Public Health Laboratories.

questionOriginal: I have recovered from COVID-19, but I am sick with a new illness and symptoms. When can I return to work, school or child care?
questionText: I have recovered from COVID-19, but I am sick with a new illness and symptoms. When can I return to work, school or child care?
answerOriginal:
If you develop new illness symptoms within the first 3 months of recovering from a COVID-19 infection, we do not recommend retesting. Data to date show that a person who has had and recovered from COVID-19 may have low levels of virus in their bodies for up to 3 months after diagnosis. This means that if the person who has recovered from COVID-19 is retested within 3 months of their initial infection, they may continue to have a positive test result, even though they are not spreading COVID-19.

You should still stay home when you are sick to prevent spreading illness to others. You should remain home until your symptoms have improved or are gone. If you have a fever, you should stay home until you are fever-free (without the use of fever-reducing medicine) for at least 24 hours. Contact your health care provider if you have questions or concerns.

Learn more about if people who recover from COVID-19 can be infected again and when you are considered to be recovered from COVID-19.

questionOriginal: I had COVID-19. Do I need to quarantine if I am a close contact of someone with COVID-19?
questionText: I had COVID-19. Do I need to quarantine if I am a close contact of someone with COVID-19?
answerOriginal:
If you had COVID-19 â and then are exposed to someone with COVID-19 (for example, you are a close contact of someone with COVID-19) â you do not need to quarantine only if:

  1. you had a positive COVID-19 test result (from a PCR or antigen test) and have met the criteria to end your isolation, and
  2. the new exposure is within the first 3 months after symptoms from your initial infection started, or within the first 3 months of your first positive test if you didnât have symptoms during your initial infection, and
  3. you have not had any COVID-19 symptoms since the new exposure.

However, you must quarantineÂ when you travel or return to Vermont under theÂ current travel guidelines and you are not allowed to gatherÂ with people you donât live with under theÂ current social gathering guidelines.

questionOriginal: I live in a border town. Do I need to quarantine if I travel to and from towns across the border?
questionText: I live in a border town. Do I need to quarantine if I travel to and from towns across the border?
answerOriginal:
A border town is considered a town that is within 5 miles of the Vermont border. Many of Vermontâs border towns are economically and culturally linked to a neighboring stateâs border towns. Vermontâs cross state travel guidance allows people to travel between border towns for certain purposes without quarantining. This means that if you are a Vermonter living in a border town or if you live in a border town in a neighboring state, you do not need to quarantine only if:

  • You travel 5 miles into a neighboring state or into Vermont.
  • You travel to a neighboring state or to Vermont and back home in the same day.
  • You travel for an essential purpose or for an activity that is necessary for your physical or mental health. This includes going to worship, going to a gym, getting a haircut, and participating in place-based outdoor recreation. This does not include activities such as social gatherings, dining at a restaurant or bar, or going to an indoor entertainment venue (for example, a movie theater or bowling alley).

You must continue to follow the COVID-19 prevention measures, including wearing a mask and staying at least 6 feet away from people you donât live with, when you are in a border town in Vermont or in a neighboring state.

questionOriginal: How long does protection from the vaccine last?
questionText: How long does protection from the vaccine last?
answerOriginal:
According to the CDC, we donât know how long protection lasts for those who are vaccinated. What we do know is that COVID-19 has caused very serious illness and death for a lot of people. If you get COVID-19, you also risk giving it to loved ones who may get very sick. Getting a COVID-19 vaccine is a safer choice.

Experts are working to learn more about both natural immunity and immunity from being vaccinated. The CDC will keep the public informed as new evidence becomes available.

questionOriginal: How long does it take for the vaccine to protect me from getting COVID-19?
questionText: How long does it take for the vaccine to protect me from getting COVID-19?
answerOriginal:
You may not be protected from COVID-19 until you are fully vaccinated, which is 14 days after your final shot. It takes time for the vaccine to train your body to fight COVID-19.

The vaccine protects you from serious illness, but we donât know for sure if you can give the virus to someone else. Some recent studies suggest that a person who is vaccinated is less likely to infect other people with the COVID-19 virus. Until enough people are vaccinated and we know more, it is important to continue following the prevention steps, like wearing a mask, keeping 6 feet apart, and washing your hands, and to follow the social gathering guidelines, even after youâve been vaccinated.

You may not be protected from COVID-19 until you are fully vaccinated, which is 14 days after your final shot. It takes time for the vaccine to train your body to fight COVID-19.
The vaccine protects you from serious illness, but we donât know for sure if you can give the virus to someone else. Some recent studies suggest that a person who is vaccinated is less likely to infect other people with the COVID-19 virus. Until enough people are vaccinated and we know more, it is important to continue following the prevention steps, like wearing a mask, keeping 6 feet apart, and washing your hands, and to follow the social gathering guidelines, even after youâve been vaccinated.

questionOriginal: Can I still infect someone with the COVID-19 virus after I've been fully vaccinated?
questionText: Can I still infect someone with the COVID-19 virus after I've been fully vaccinated?
answerOriginal:
You may not be protected from COVID-19 until you are fully vaccinated, which is 14 days after your final shot. While the vaccine protects you from serious illness, we donât know yet if you can give the virus to someone else.

However, some recent studies suggest that a person who is vaccinated is less likely to infect other people with the COVID-19 virus. Until more research is done, it is important that you continue to follow the prevention steps, like wearing a mask, keeping 6 feet apart, and washing your hands, and to follow the social gathering guidelines, even after youâve been vaccinated.

Learn more about the studies:

  • Decreased SARS-CoV-2 viral load following vaccination
  • Transmission of COVID-19 in 282 clusters in Catalonia, Spain: a cohort study

questionOriginal: How much does the COVID-19 vaccine cost?
questionText: How much does the COVID-19 vaccine cost?
answerOriginal: COVID-19 vaccines are free. COVID-19 vaccines are provided to Vermonters at no cost, even if you donât have health insurance. The provider that gives you your vaccine may charge an administrative fee to your insurance, but you are guaranteed a COVID-19 vaccine without paying a fee.
answerText:
COVID-19 vaccines are free. COVID-19 vaccines are provided to Vermonters at no cost, even if you donât have health insurance.
You are guaranteed a COVID-19 vaccine without paying a fee. The provider that gives you your vaccine may charge an administrative fee to your insurance. If you donât have insurance, there is a federal grant that will pay for any administrative fees.
When you make an appointment to be vaccinated, you will be asked to provide your health insurance information. Insurance is not required, and someone who doesnât have insurance will still be able to get a vaccine. But being able to bill someoneâs primary insurance does help offset some of the costs.

questionOriginal: I am not able to leave my home. How can I get the vaccine?
questionText: I am not able to leave my home. How can I get the vaccine?
answerOriginal:
We are currently working on a plan to make sure people who are unable to leave their home can get a COVID-19 vaccine. We hope to work with emergency medical services agencies across Vermont to provide in-home vaccinations to people who need it.

These in-home vaccine visits havenât started yet, and probably wonât be ready in the next phase of vaccine distribution, but we are working hard to make this possible and will put more information on our website as soon as possible.
answerText:
Homebound means you are not able to leave your home for scheduled medical or non-medical appointments. If you are currently eligible to get the vaccine and are homebound, you will be able to get the vaccine in your home.
If you are in the service of a local home health agency, the agency will reach out to you to schedule an appointment.
If you are not in the service of a home health agency, you may request an appointment by calling 802-863-7240 (toll-free 833-722-0860) Monday through Friday from 8:30 a.m. to 4:30 p.m.
Please do not make a request if you have already made one through your primary care provider, hospital, or home health agency. There is enough vaccine for everyone who is homebound. However, it will take time to reach everyone in need. In most cases, your appointment will be scheduled 10 to 14 days after you make a request.

questionOriginal: What can I do after I am fully vaccinated?
questionText: What can I do after I am fully vaccinated?
answerOriginal:
You are fully vaccinated 14 days after your final shot. Until you are fully vaccinated, you should follow the same guidance as unvaccinated people. Learn about why it is important to get two doses of the Pfizer-BioNTech or Moderna vaccine.

Continue Prevention

Continue takingÂ steps to prevent COVID-19, except as described below.

The vaccine protects you from illness, but we donât know for sure if you can give the virus to someone else. Some recent studies suggest that a person who is vaccinated is less likely to infect other people with the COVID-19 virus. Until enough people are vaccinated and we know more, it is important to continue to follow prevention steps and continue to wear a mask, keep 6 feet apart, and wash your hands.

Gathering with Others

The following guidance only applies in non-health care settings.

  • You may gather with other fully vaccinated people indoors without wearing masks or staying 6 feet apart.
  • You may also gather with unvaccinated people from one household indoors without wearing masks or staying 6 feet apart, as long as everyone in that household is at low risk for severe COVID-19.

If you gather with people from more than one unvaccinated household, or with someone who is at higher risk of severe COVID-19, you must wear a mask and keep a 6-foot distance. SeeÂ details on gathering restrictions in Vermont.

Travel

You may travel to or return to Vermont without quarantine. Find outÂ more about travel, includingÂ staying in someone's home.

Close Contact of Someone with COVID-19

If you are a close contact of someone with COVID-19, as long as you do not have symptoms and are not in a health care setting:

  • You do not need to seek testing.
  • You do not need to quarantine.

questionOriginal: I am fully vaccinated. Do I need to quarantine if I am a close contact of someone with COVID-19?
questionText: I am fully vaccinated. Do I need to quarantine if I am a close contact of someone with COVID-19?
answerOriginal:
If it has been 14 days since you got your final vaccine dose, and then you are exposed to someone with COVID-19 (for example, you are a close contact of someone with COVID-19), you do not need to quarantine only if:

  • you are within 3 months of receiving your second dose of the vaccine, and
  • you have not had any COVID-19 symptoms since the new exposure.

However, vaccinated inpatients and residents in health care settings will still need to quarantine if they are a close contact of someone with COVID-19. Read the CDCâs guidance.

This guidance does not apply to health care workers in certain situations.

However, you are not allowed to gatherÂ with people you donât live with under theÂ current social gathering guidelines.
answerText:
No. You do not need to quarantine if it has been 14 days since you got your final vaccine dose, and then you are exposed to someone with COVID-19 (for example, you are a close contact of someone with COVID-19),Â and you have not had any COVID-19 symptoms since the new exposure.
However, vaccinated inpatients and residents in health care settings will still need to quarantine if they are a close contact of someone with COVID-19. Read the CDCâs guidance.
This guidance does not apply to health care workers in certain situations.

questionOriginal: How many people are being monitored in Vermont?
questionText: How many people are being monitored in Vermont?
answerOriginal: The number of people being monitored is updated every day on the Current Activity in Vermont data dashboard.
answerText: You can find information about Vermontâs COVID-19 vaccination progress on the COVID-19 Vaccine Dashboard, including the number of doses received, total people started, total people completed, percentage of overall progress and percentage completed. The dashboard is updated Tuesdays through Saturdays.

questionOriginal: Can people who recover from COVID-19 be infected again?
questionText: Can people who recover from COVID-19 be infected again?
answerOriginal: The immune response to COVID-19 is not yet understood. Patients with another type of coronavirus, MERS-CoV (also known as MERS) are unlikely to be re-infected shortly after they recover, but it is not yet known whether this is true for people sick from COVID-19.
answerText:
People who haveÂ recoveredÂ from COVID-19 can be infected again. Current data show that a person who had COVID-19 and recovered from it may have small amounts of the virusâs genetic materials in their body for at least three months after they were diagnosed with COVID-19. This means that if you have recovered from COVID-19 and are tested within three months of your initial infection, you may continue to have a positive test result.
The likelihood of a person being reinfected with COVID-19 within three months of their initial infection is low. Research regarding this is ongoing. Therefore, if you have recovered from COVID-19 and have new symptoms of COVID-19, you may need to be evaluated to see if you have COVID-19 again, especially if you are a close contact of someone with COVID-19. In this case, you should isolate and contact your health care provider to be evaluated for other causes of your symptoms, and possibly retested.

questionOriginal: What are the current restrictions on gatherings?
questionText: What are the current restrictions on gatherings?
answerOriginal:
These are the current restrictions on social gatherings in Vermont (exceptions listed below):

  • You are not allowed to gather with people you donât live with. This includes all inside and outside social and entertainment gatherings, and in public and private spaces. For example, this means you cannot go over to a family member or friendâs house or go to a restaurant with someone you donât live with.
  • Visitors to Vermont are not allowed to gather with Vermonters or with people from another household. This includes sharing lodging with another household. Travelers may not stay with a Vermont host or stay in a Vermont lodging establishment or short-term rental with another household. Even if they have completed quarantine, or intend to quarantine with another household, they may not gather with another household in Vermont.

There are some exceptions to these restrictions. This is what is allowed:

  • If you are fully vaccinated (it has been 14 days since your final vaccine dose), you may gather with one other household at a time, even if the people in the household are not vaccinated. This also means that if everyone in a household is fully vaccinated, then they can gather with another household that is not vaccinated. Since children cannot get vaccinated at this time, a household with children is not considered a fully vaccinated household. This guidance also applies to visitors to Vermont. Learn about Vermonters hosting visitors in their homes.
  • If you live alone, you may gather with people who live in one other household.
  • You can take in and shelter people from another household who are living in a dangerous, unhealthy or otherwise unsafe situation.
  • You can do outdoor recreation and fitness activities with people you donât live with, like biking, hiking, walking, running, hunting and fishing, skiing, snowboarding, skating, snow machining and other no-contact outdoor activities. However, you must stay at least 6 feet away from people you donât live with and wear a mask at all times. Do not gather at trailheads, access areas or other outdoor facilities before or after the activity.

It is not considered a social gathering if you have contact with someone for less than 15 minutes, you both are wearing masks, and you stay at least 6 feet apart (for example, checking on a neighbor, friend or family member not in your household). You are allowed to come in contact with members of other households in settings that continue to operate â such as schools, workplaces, retail stores, close contact businesses, etc. â as long as all the required health protocols are followed.

If you do gather with people you donât live with, you should quarantine. Quarantine means staying home and away from other people for 14 days. The Health Department strongly encourages you to get tested before the gathering, as soon as 2 days after the gathering, and again 7 days after the gathering. If you have not had symptoms of COVID-19, you have the option to get a PCR test on day 7 and end your quarantine with a negative test result.

Read Governor Scottâs Executive Order on social gathering restrictions.
answerText:
Vermont has restrictions on social gatherings based on whether you are fully vaccinated or not. You are fully vaccinated 14 days after your final shot. Since children cannot get vaccinated at this time, a household with children is not considered a fully vaccinated household.
If you are fully vaccinated:

You may gather with other fully vaccinated people or households. You donât need to wear a mask or stay 6 feet apart when you gather.
You may gather with up to two unvaccinated people or households at a time. The gathering can also include other vaccinated people or households. If you gather with people from more than one unvaccinated household, or with someone who is at higher risk of severe COVID-19 or lives with someone at higher risk, everyone should wear a mask and stay 6 feet apart.

If you are not fully vaccinated:

You may gather with fully vaccinated people or households. You donât need to wear a mask or stay 6 feet apart, unless someone is at higher risk of severe COVID-19 or lives with someone at higher risk.
You may gather with one other unvaccinated person or household at a time. Fully vaccinated people or households can also be at the gathering. Everyone should wear a mask and stay 6 feet apart.
You can do outdoor recreation and fitness activities with anyone. This includes biking, hiking, walking, running, hunting and fishing, skiing, snowboarding, skating, snow machining and other no-contact outdoor activities. However, you must stay at least 6 feet away from people you donât live with and wear a mask at all times. Do not gather at trailheads, access areas or other outdoor facilities before or after the activity.
If you live alone, you may gather with people who live in one other household.
You can take in and shelter people from another household who are living in a dangerous, unhealthy or otherwise unsafe situation.

If you are a visitor traveling to Vermont and staying at a lodging establishment, short-term rental, or with friends and family, must follow these gathering restrictions. Staying with another household is considered a social gathering and you must follow the rules listed above. Learn more about Vermonters hosting visitors in their homes.
It is not considered a social gathering if you have contact with someone for less than 15 minutes, you both are wearing masks, and you stay at least 6 feet apart (for example, checking on a neighbor, friend or family member not in your household). You are allowed to come in contact with members of other households in settings that continue to operate â such as schools, workplaces, retail stores, close contact businesses, etc. â as long as all the required health protocols are followed.

questionOriginal: What is known about variants of the COVID-19 virus?
questionText: What is known about variants of the COVID-19 virus?
answerOriginal:
Viruses constantly change through mutation, and new variants of a virus are expected to occur over time. Information about these variants is rapidly emerging. Scientists are working to learn more about how easily they spread, whether they could cause more severe illness, and whether currently authorized vaccines will protect people against them.

Multiple COVID-19 variants are circulating globally, namely in the United Kingdom (UK), South Africa and Brazil. According to the CDC, these variants seem to spread more easily and quickly than other variants, which may lead to more cases of COVID-19. You can find a map showing the number of confirmed cases caused by variants in the U.S.

The Health Department is working to detect any potential variants of concern â through genetic sequencing of certain specimens taken from various parts of the state and through wastewater testing in Burlington. We will continue this work, to help Vermonters understand any changes in the virus that may require us to strengthen our prevention efforts.

Here is what you can do to protect yourself and your community:

  • Keep up with prevention steps, like wearing masks, staying 6 feet apart, staying home if you are sick, washing your hands often, and avoiding crowded places. Prevention steps continue to be effective against variants.
  • Get tested if you think you have been exposed to COVID-19 or if you think you have any symptoms, even if they are mild. While a test is not able to determine if a variant is present, knowing that you have COVID-19 as soon as possible will help protect yourself and your community.
  • Get vaccinated when you are eligible. So far, studies suggest that the vaccines available now will help our bodies fight against strains of the virus that causes COVID-19.

Variants in Vermont

  • The B.1.1.7 variant, first identified in the UK, has now been detected in many U.S. states, including Vermont. The CDC anticipates the more easily transmissible B.1.1.7 variant will become the dominant strain in the country.
  • The B.1.429 variant, first identified in California, has been detected in Vermont.

Learn more about what we know, what we donât know, and what the CDC is doing about variants of the COVID-19 virus.

questionOriginal: Can I make a vaccine appointment for someone else? How do I sign someone up as a dependent?
questionText: Can I make a vaccine appointment for someone else? How do I sign someone up as a dependent?
answerOriginal:
Yes, you can make an appointment for your loved one or someone you care for who is 75 years or older, especially if they need help registering online.

If you are making an appointment online for a spouse or partner at the same time as your own, you will need to make the appointments individually. Learn more about making two appointments at the same time.

If you are a case worker who is scheduling an appointment for your client, please call 855-722-7878 Monday through Friday from 8:15 a.m. â 5:30 p.m. and Saturday to Sunday 10:00 a.m. â 3:00 p.m.

If you are scheduling an appointment for a family member, we recommend that you create an account, and then sign them up as a âdependent.â

First, you need to create an account in the registration system. You will need an email address to create an account, and can use the same address for more than one person. Learn more about what to do if you donât have an email address.

If you already have an account because you were tested for COVID-19 through a Health Department site, you need to use the same account information to schedule an appointment to get a vaccine. The registration system will not allow you to create a new account if you use an email address that is already in the system. If you already have an account, go to the âadding them as a dependentâ steps below.

Here is how you create an account:

  • Go to the COVID-19 Event Portal.
  • Enter your name, phone number, email address, and date of birth.
  • Click the âcreate accountâ button.

After you create an account, an email is immediately sent to the email address you entered. You will need to verify your account on the COVID-19 Event Portal to make the personâs appointment:

  • Click on the link in the email sent to you to verify your account.
  • Enter your Patient ID number.
  • Create a password.
  • Review and consent to the Notice of Privacy Practices.
  • Enter your personal information.

Next, you need to add them as a dependent. Click on the âAdd Dependent/Spouseâ button at the top of the screen. After consenting, you will need to enter their personal information:

  • Name
  • Email address (use your email, the same one used to set up your account)
  • Phone number
  • Date of birth
  • Address

If the person getting the vaccine does not live in Vermont, the system will ask do they work in Vermont, get primary care in Vermont, or recently moved to Vermont. If none of these apply, they wonât be able to get vaccinated in Vermont, and should seek a vaccine in the state where they live.

Then, click the âSchedule Vaccine Appointmentâ button at the top of the screen and select their name. Select a clinic site location by searching by county and date range.

Next, you will answer a series of medical (see below) and demographic questions as well as questions about any COVID-19 symptoms the person has. You will be asked to provide their health insurance information. Insurance is not required, and there is no cost for getting the vaccine. You will be asked to complete a waiver.

Finally, choose an appointment slot from the list of available appointments. Click the âsubmitâ button. You will immediately receive an email confirmation.

These are the medical screening questions asked:

  1. Have you ever had an immediate allergic reaction to any other vaccine or injectable therapy, an immediate allergic reaction of any severity to a previous dose of an mRNA COVID-19 vaccine or any of its components (including polyethylene glycol [PEG]), or an immediate allergic reaction of any severity to polysorbate? If the answer is yes, then they cannot get any of the currently available COVID-19 vaccines. They should consider contacting their health care provider if they have questions.
  2. Are you currently sick with COVID-19 or still in your isolation period following a COVID-19 infection? If the answer is yes, then they cannot get a COVID-19 vaccine at this time, but can schedule an appointment at a later date.
  3. Have you received another vaccine in the last 14 days? If the answer is yes, then they won't be able to schedule an appointment right now, but can log back in at a later date to schedule an appointment.
  4. Do you have a weakened immune system caused by something such as HIV infection or cancer or do you take immunosuppressive drugs or therapies? If the answer is yes, then they can make an appointment but they will be advised to talk with their health care provider before getting vaccinated.
  5. Do you have a history of a bleeding disorder or are you taking a blood thinner? If the answer is yes, then they can still get a vaccine, but they may want to talk with their health care provider first about any concerns. People with bleeding disorders or who are taking blood thinners may bruise or have more serious bleeding after injections. Special precautions can be taken to help avoid post-injection bleeding and bruising, such as using a very fine needle and applying pressure to the injection site after the injection.
  6. Are you pregnant? If the answer is yes, then they can make an appointment but they will be advised to talk with their health care provider before getting vaccinated.
  7. Are you breastfeeding or lactating? If the answer is yes, then they can make an appointment but they will be advised to talk with their health care provider before getting vaccinated.
  8. Have you received passive antibody therapy as treatment for COVID-19 in the past 90 days? If the answer is yes, then they will need to wait for 90 days before scheduling an appointment.

You can also watch a video on how to make an appointment online.
answerText:
Yes. You can make an appointment for your loved one or someone you care for who is currently eligible, especially if they need help creating an account and making an appointment online.
Anyone who is unable to make their appointment online, needs help, or who wants to speak with someone in a language other than English can call 855-722-7878.
If you are making an appointment online for a spouse or partner at the same time as your own, you will need to make the appointments individually. Learn more about making two appointments at the same time.
If you are a case worker who is scheduling an appointment for your client, please call 855-722-7878 Monday through Friday from 8:15 a.m. â 5:30 p.m. and Saturday to Sunday 10:00 a.m. â 3:00 p.m.
If you are scheduling an appointment for a family member, we recommend that you create an account, and then sign them up as a âdependent.â You can watch a video on how to make an appointment online and find tips for making an appointment. Here are the steps you will need to take:
1. Create an account.
First, you will need to create an account in our online system. You will need an email address to create an account, and can use the same address for more than one person. Learn more about what to do if you donât have an email address.
If you already have an account because you were tested for COVID-19 through a Health Department site, you need to use the same account information to schedule an appointment to get a vaccine. The system will not allow you to create a new account if you use an email address that is already in the system.
If you already have an account, start at the âadd a dependentâ step below.
Here is how you create an account:

Go to the COVID-19 Event Portal.
Enter your name, phone number, email address, and date of birth.
Click the âcreate accountâ button.

After you create an account, an email is immediately sent to the email address you entered. You will need to verify your account on the COVID-19 Event Portal to make the personâs appointment:

Click on the link in the email sent to you to confirm your account.
Enter your Patient ID number.
Enter your email and date of birth.
Create a password.
Review and consent to the Notice of Privacy Practices.
Enter your personal demographic information.
Enter your vaccine eligibility information, including your pass code (if applicable).

2. Add a dependent.
You will need to add them as a dependent. You can watch a video on how to add a dependent to your account. Click on the âAdd Dependent/Spouseâ button at the top of the screen. After consenting, you will need to enter their personal information:

Name
Email address (use your email, the same one used to set up your account)
Phone number
Select how you would like to receive communication and documents from the Health Department.
Date of birth
Address
Enter their vaccine eligibility information, including their pass code (if applicable).

If the person getting the vaccine does not live in Vermont, the system will ask do they work in Vermont, get primary care in Vermont, or recently moved to Vermont. If none of these apply, they wonât be able to get vaccinated in Vermont, and should seek a vaccine in the state where they live.
3. Schedule a vaccine appointment.
Click the âSchedule Vaccine Appointmentâ button at the top of the screen and select their name. Select a clinic site location by searching by county and date range.
Next, you will answer a series of medical (see below) and demographic questions as well as questions about any COVID-19 symptoms the person has. You will be asked to provide their health insurance information. Insurance is not required, and there is no cost for getting the vaccine. You also will be asked to complete a waiver.
Finally, choose an appointment slot from the list of available appointments. Click the âsubmitâ button. You may be redirected to choose a different location and time depending on your vaccine eligibility. Once you make an appointment, you will immediately receive an email confirmation.
These are the medical screening questions asked:

Have you had a severe allergic reaction (e.g., anaphylaxis) after a previous dose of the Pfizer or Moderna COVID-19 vaccine or any of its components? If the answer is yes, then they cannot get a vaccine. They should consider contacting their health care provider if they have questions.
Have you had an immediate allergic reaction to any other vaccine or injectable therapy? If the answer is yes, then they will be asked to contact their health care provider for a referral to an allergy/immunology specialist who can determine if they can safely receive the vaccine.
Are you currently sick with COVID-19 or still in your isolation period following a COVID-19 infection? If the answer is yes, then they cannot get a COVID-19 vaccine at this time, but can schedule an appointment at a later date.
Have you had a vaccine in the past 14 days or is a vaccination scheduled in the next 8 weeks? If the answer is yes, then they cannot get a COVID-19 vaccine at this time, but can schedule an appointment at a later date.
Have you received passive antibody therapy as treatment for COVID-19 in the past 90 days? If the answer is yes, then they will need to wait for 90 days before scheduling an appointment.
Do you have a weakened immune system caused by something such as HIV infection or cancer or do you take immunosuppressive drugs or therapies? If the answer is yes, they can make an appointment, but they will be advised to talk with their health care provider before getting vaccinated.
Are you pregnant? If the answer is yes, they can make an appointment, but they will be advised to talk with their health care provider before getting vaccinated.
Are you lactating or breastfeeding? If the answer is yes, they can make an appointment, but they will be advised to talk with their health care provider before getting vaccinated.

questionOriginal: What is self-observation?
questionText: What is self-observation?
answerOriginal:
Self-observation is for other Vermonters who donât have symptoms of COVID-19. Follow these prevention steps to keep from getting or spreading COVID-19:

These are things you can do to keep from getting or spreading COVID-19:

  • Stay home if you are sick.
  • Wash your hands often.
  • Keep your social circle small.
  • Stay at least 6 feet away from people you don't live with.
  • Wear a mask when youâre outside and canât keep 6 feet apart or anytime youâre inside with people you donât live with.

Learn more about why, how and when to do these things and about isolation, quarantine and self-observation.
answerText:
Self-observation is for Vermonters who donât have symptoms of COVID-19. Follow these prevention steps to keep from getting or spreading COVID-19:

Stay home if you are sick.
Wash your hands often.
Keep your social circle small.
Stay at least 6Â feet apart.
Wear a mask.

Learn more about isolation, quarantine and self-observation.

questionOriginal: What are the ingredients in the COVID-19 vaccines?
questionText: What are the ingredients in the COVID-19 vaccines?
answerOriginal:
The ingredients in the Pfizer-BioNTech and Moderna COVID-19 vaccines are similar to what is found in other vaccines â both contain the mRNA protein, fats, salts, and sugars. They do not have any fetal tissue, animal products, eggs, gelatin, latex, or preservatives in them.

Learn more about which vaccines are available in Vermont.
answerText:
The ingredients in the COVID-19 vaccines are similar to what is found in other vaccines. They contain protein, and fats, salts and polysorbate. The mRNA vaccines (Pfizer-BioNTech and Moderna) also have sugars and polyethylene glycol. They do not have any fetal tissue, pork products, eggs, gelatin, latex or preservatives in them.
Learn more about which vaccines are available in Vermont.

questionOriginal: I am an undocumented immigrant living in Vermont. Can I get the vaccine?
questionText: I am an undocumented immigrant living in Vermont. Can I get the vaccine?
answerOriginal:
Yes. You can get the vaccine when you are eligible based on age, health condition, job or setting.

When you make a vaccine appointment, you may be asked for certain information. The only answers that are needed to make a vaccine appointment are your name, date of birth, and address. This information is kept confidential since it is legally protected personal health information. If you live in Vermont but do not have an address or do not feel comfortable sharing this information, you can answer "UNKNOWN" in the street address field. You will still need to select âVTâ from the state dropdown field.

Make an appointment to get the COVID-19 vaccine.

Learn more about equal access to the vaccine for undocumented immigrants.

questionOriginal: Iâm afraid of or triggered by needles. How can I get the vaccine?
questionText: Iâm afraid of or triggered by needles. How can I get the vaccine?
answerOriginal:
Many people are afraid of getting vaccines because they are often given with a needle. The physical reaction inside you is very real. There are ways to overcome these fears through conditioning and practice. This can help you get the COVID-19 vaccine and other lifesaving vaccines or medical treatments you may need during your life.

Here are a few things you can do:

  • Talk to your provider about what you can expect. Knowing what is coming can help.
  • Remember to breathe. This helps calm your body and mind.
  • Distract yourself from the procedure. Fix your focus on something else like a magazine or bring a support person to help.
  • Look away from the needle.
  • Think positive thoughts. Tell yourself that you are getting a shot for protection. Tell yourself you can do it. Then the more you do it, the easier it should be next time.

questionOriginal: I am a parent. What do I need to know, and how can I help keep my children safe from COVID-19?
questionText: I am a parent. What do I need to know, and how can I help keep my children safe from COVID-19?
answerOriginal:
There are gathering restrictions in Vermont. You are not allowed to gather with people you donât live with. But if you are fully vaccinated, you can gather with one other household at a time. Learn more about Vermontâs gathering restrictions and exceptions.

If you do gather with people you donât live with, you should quarantine. Quarantine means staying home and away from other people for 14 days. The Health Department strongly encourages you to get tested before the gathering, as soon as 2 days after the gathering, and again 7 days after the gathering. If you have not had symptoms of COVID-19, you have the option to get a PCR test on day 7 and end your quarantine with a negative test result.

If you are around other people, itâs safest to be outdoors. Because of the nature of how the virus spreads and how it survives, being indoors increases your risk of spreading or getting COVID-19.

Gathering in groups or âpodsâ related to education or child care that are already formed can continue. Gathering in pods related to social activity, informal playgroups, playdates, or sleepovers are not allowed at this time. New pods of any kind are discouraged.

For outdoor recreation with people you donât live with, keep a physical distance of at least 6 feet and wear a mask. There are no other limitations to outdoor activities. Being active outside is good for our mental and physical health!

Follow these general prevention steps to keep from getting or spreading COVID-19:

  • Stay home if you are sick.
  • Wash your hands often.
  • Keep your social circle small. At this time, your social circle should only include the people you live with.
  • Stay at least 6 feet away from people you don't live with.
  • Wear a mask (children over 2 who are able) anytime you are around people you donât live with.

There will always be some risk of COVID-19 when we leave home, but it is possible to live your life and stay safer. Look for three things to help weigh the risk when making plans or going out:

  • 6-Foot Spaces: Can I easily keep 6 feet from others?
  • Masks on Faces: Will people wear masks?
  • Uncrowded Places: Is there enough space for people to spread out?

Imagine these things as layers protecting us from getting and spreading COVID-19. The more layers we have, the lower the risk. Find more tips on preventing COVID-19.

Children can also continue to take advantage of technology to play games or keep in touch with friends and family. These changes will continue to be difficult, but we are all doing our part to slow down this pandemic.

Learn more:

  • Resources for families with children
  • Coping with family stress during COVID-19
  • Face coverings for children
  • Frequently asked questions about school and child care

questionOriginal: I am pregnant or breastfeeding. Should I get vaccinated?
questionText: I am pregnant or breastfeeding. Should I get vaccinated?
answerOriginal:
Based on how mRNA vaccines work, experts believe they are unlikely to pose a specific risk for people who are pregnant. However, the actual risks of mRNA vaccines to the pregnant person and their fetus are unknown because these vaccines have not been studied in pregnant people. Pregnant people have a slightly higher risk for poor outcomes, as do their fetuses, with COVID-19 infection. Studies are on-going.

If you are pregnant and part of a group that is recommended to receive the vaccine (for example, health care personnel), you may choose to be vaccinated. The CDC and other professional organizations recommend that you consult with your health care provider.

There are no data on the safety of COVID-19 vaccines in people who are breastfeeding or the effects of mRNA vaccines on milk production/excretion or on the breastfed baby. mRNA vaccines are not thought to be a risk to the breastfed baby. A person who is breastfeeding and is part of a group recommended to receive a COVID-19 vaccine (for example, health care personnel) may choose to be vaccinated.
answerText:
Pregnant people are at an increased risk for severe illness and for poor pregnancy outcomes if they get COVID-19. Any of the vaccines can be given to people who are pregnant or breastfeeding.
The three vaccines have not been studied in pregnant people. But medical and scientific experts believe they are unlikely to pose a risk to the pregnant person or fetus because the vaccines cannot copy themselves in the body or cause infection. TheÂ American College of Obstetrics and GynecologyÂ recommendsÂ that COVID-19 vaccines should not be withheld from people who are pregnant, want to become pregnant, or who are lactating.
There are no data on the safety of COVID-19 vaccines in people who are breastfeeding or the effects of the vaccines on milk production/excretion or on the breastfed baby. Since these vaccines do not reproduce inside your bodyâs cells, they are not thought to be a risk to the breastfed baby.
The CDC and other professional organizations recommend that you talk with your health care provider if you have any questions about the vaccines.
For more information, watch the video Sara Asks about the COVID-19 Vaccine, which is also available in other languages.

questionOriginal: I have recovered from COVID-19. Can I donate my blood plasma to help other people suffering from COVID-19?
questionText: I have recovered from COVID-19. Can I donate my blood plasma to help other people suffering from COVID-19?
answerOriginal:
People who have fully recovered from COVID-19 have antibodies in their blood plasma. This is the bodyâs immune response to the virus. Currently, plasma donations are only being done experimentally. It has not yet been confirmed by the scientific community. However, it could prove to be important in the future to treating serious cases of illness from COVID-19.

The Red Cross is looking for people who are fully recovered from COVID-19 and may be able to donate plasma. If you are fully recovered from a COVID-19 diagnosis that was confirmed by a lab test and would like to donate your plasma, fill out the form on the Red Cross website.
answerText:
If youâve fully recovered from COVID-19, the plasma in your blood may contain COVID-19 antibodies that can attack the virus. Plasma is being evaluated as a possible treatment for people who are currently sick with COVID-19.
The Red Cross is looking for people who have fully recovered from COVID-19 and would like to donate their plasma. If you are interested in donating your plasma, fill out the form on the Red Cross website.

questionOriginal: Do I need to wait to get my vaccine if I am under quarantine or isolation?
questionText: Do I need to wait to get my vaccine if I am under quarantine or isolation?
answerOriginal:
Yes. You will need to postpone your appointment for the first dose or second dose until you have completed your quarantine or isolation period.

If you are under quarantine because you were exposed to someone who tested positive for COVID-19 or because you traveled, you should wait to get your vaccine until you are able to end your quarantine.

If you tested positive for COVID-19 and are still in your isolation period, you should wait to get your vaccine until you are able to end your isolation.
answerText:
If you are under quarantine, you can leave quarantine to get your first or second dose of the vaccine. However, if you have symptoms of COVID-19, contact your health care provider. You will need to stay home and reschedule your appointment.
If you tested positive for COVID-19 and are still in your isolation period, you will need to wait to get your first or second dose until you are able to end your isolation.
There are enough appointment slots available for everyone who is eligible. You will be able to easily get another appointment. Find out how to reschedule your appointment.

questionOriginal: Do COVID-19 vaccines cause infertility?
questionText: Do COVID-19 vaccines cause infertility?
answerOriginal:
There is no scientific evidence that the Pfizer-BioNTech or the Moderna vaccines cause infertility, according to the Food and Drug Administration. These are mRNA vaccines, which means they are rapidly broken down in the cell. They do not go into your DNA and do not cause mutations, cellular defects or infertility, according to the American Academy of Family Physicians.

Learn more about how mRNA vaccines work.
answerText:
There is no evidence that fertility problems are a side effect of any vaccine, including COVID-19 vaccines.Â The American College of Obstetrics and GynecologyÂ recommends the vaccine for anyone who may want to get pregnant in the future.Â The vaccinesÂ do notÂ go intoÂ yourÂ DNA.
Learn more aboutÂ how mRNA vaccines (Pfizer-BioNTech and Moderna) work.
Learn more about how vector vaccines (Johnson & Johnson) work.

questionOriginal: How is Vermont deciding when it is safe to reopen?
questionText: How is Vermont deciding when it is safe to reopen?
answerOriginal:
Most recent modeling data suggests Vermont has reached its peak in the number of new cases of COVID-19, hospital capacity, and the number people who are currently infected with COVID-19.

However, it is important to remember that not everyone infected with the virus has symptoms and there are still many people who are currently infected and could spread it to others.

Vermont is looking at four key measures to inform steps to reopen:

  • Ongoing reduction in cases for at least 14 days
  • A health care system that is safely able to treat all patients without exceeding its capacity or using crisis standards of care
  • The ability to test all people with symptoms
  • Widespread active monitoring of people who have tested positive for COVID-19 and tracing their close contacts

At this time, Vermont continues to do well in keeping the number of cases of COVID-19 down. This is hopeful news. To continue on this path, it is critical that Vermonters continue to follow the general precautions to keep the virus from spreading and to help save lives: wear a cloth face mask or covering, keep a 6-foot distance from others, wash your hands often, and stay home if you are sick.

Read the latest Vermont COVID-19 modeling projections from the Vermont Department of Financial Regulation.
answerText:
Governor Scott released a phased reopening plan â Vermont Forward -- to help Vermonters and local businesses see the path for a phased return to unrestricted travel, business operations, and event gatherings. The plan was developed by the Department of Health, the Department of Public Safety, and the Agency of Commerce and Community Development and uses vaccination milestones to ensure a safe easing of personal restrictions and continued reopening of the state's economy.
Learn about the Vermont Forward Plan.
Read the latest Vermont COVID-19 modeling projections from the Vermont Department of Financial Regulation.

questionOriginal: I have a high-risk health condition. How do I make an appointment for a vaccine?
questionText: I have a high-risk health condition. How do I make an appointment for a vaccine?
answerOriginal:
There are certain medical conditions that put people at increased risk for severe illness from COVID-19 as identified by the CDC. If you have a high-risk health condition (listed below), you do not need to contact your health care provider to get documentation of the condition.

You will make an appointment in our system in the same way as Vermonters who have been eligible by age.

You will be asked some questions. First, you will say that you have one of the health conditions that makes you eligible for a vaccine. This will serve as a self-certification. We trust you to work with us and help make sure that these Vermonters at highest risk due to a medical condition are protected.

When making your appointment, you will also be asked to provide information for a health care provider you see for the condition, if you have one. But if you donât have a health care provider, you can still get a vaccine.

The Health Department may use the information you provided to confirm your eligibility, either through medical records or by contacting your provider. We may also reach out to people who donât have a provider to offer a connection to care.

Make an appointment to get the COVID-19 vaccine.

The high-risk health conditions are:

  • Current cancer
  • Chronic kidney disease
  • COPD, including emphysema and chronic bronchitis
  • Heart disease, including heart attack, heart failure, congestive heart failure, coronary artery disease (angina, acute and chronic ischemic heart disease), cardiomyopathies, and pulmonary hypertension. Does NOT include high blood pressure.
  • Immunocompromised (weakened immune system), due to solid organ transplant, blood, or bone marrow transplant, immune deficiencies, or other causes; or HIV with a low CD4 cell count or not on HIV treatment; prolonged use of corticosteroids or other immune-suppressing drugs.
  • Severe obesity (BMI of 40 or above)
  • Pregnancy
  • Type 1 and Type 2 diabetes
  • Disabilities including chromosomal disorders, such as Down syndrome; intellectual disabilities (IQ of 70 or below); disabilities that compromise lung function (neurologic and muscular conditions such as muscular dystrophy, spina bifida, and multiple sclerosis)
  • Sickle cell disease
answerText:
There are enough appointments for everyone who is eligible. Appointments are required. Clinics cannot accept walk-ins. Find out who is eligible.
Already have an account set up? Log in to your account to make an appointment.
Anyone who is unable to make their appointment online, needs help, or who wants to speak with someone in a language other than English can call 855-722-7878.
Create an Account
You will need to create an account in our online system first, and then log in to schedule your appointment. Even if youâre not currently eligible to get a vaccine, you can set up an account ahead of time.
You will need an email address to create an account, and can use the same address for more than one person. Learn more about what to do if you donât have an email address.
If you already have an account because you were tested for COVID-19 through a Health Department site, you need to use the same account information to schedule an appointment to get a vaccine. The online system will not allow you to create a new account if you use an email address that is already in the system.
Create an account.
Make a Vaccine Appointment
If you are eligible, find out what information you need and how to make a vaccine appointment.
You can also watch videos on how to:

make your vaccine appointment online
make an appointment if you are eligible by high-risk health condition or organization
add a dependent or spouse to your account

You can find a different appointment or adjust other appointment search criteria without losing your information. Click âCANCELâ to leave the âSchedule Appointmentâ screen, click on âSearch Eventâ in the menu to the left, change your search criteria, and then click âSchedule Appointmentâ to jump back to where you were.
Talk with your health care provider if you've had an immediate allergic reaction to any other vaccine, injectable therapy, or polysorbate, or if you have questions about whether getting the vaccine is right for you because of health conditions, allergies, or other vaccines you've received recently. Read the health screening questions asked before you get the vaccine.
For more information:

Tips for making a vaccine appointment
How to make a vaccine appointment for someone else
What to do if you have problems scheduling a vaccine appointment
What to expect at your vaccine appointment
Frequently asked questions about vaccine registration and appointments
Who will be eligible next to get the vaccine

questionOriginal: What is the Health Department doing?
questionText: What is the Health Department doing?
answerOriginal:
The Vermont Department of Health is working closely with long-term care facilities and other group living facilities to prepare for COVID-19 cases and prevent outbreaks, by reviewing CDC guidance for infection control and supporting development of strategies and plans. If cases occur in these settings, the Vermont Department of Health helps the facility implement control measures and prevent additional cases.

The Department does contact tracing to investigate possible travel or exposure history and to identify anyone who had close contact with the person who has tested positive for COVID-19. Those individuals will be assessed for their exposure risk and provided with guidance for their health. Where appropriate, they will receive recommendations for self-isolation or other restrictions. Please note, the Health Department only uses a live person for contact tracing and never uses anything that sounds like a âroboâ (computer-generated voice) call.

Find up-to-date information on the Health Department's COVID-19 website.
answerText:
People diagnosed with COVID-19 may have below-normal levels of oxygen in their blood before they feel short of breath. Finding low oxygen levels early helps people know that they need to seek medical care sooner. This could make the disease less severe.
The Health Department has a program that gives people who have tested positive for COVID-19 a free pulse oximeter to use at home. A pulse oximeter is a small device that clips onto your fingertip to measure your pulse and the oxygen levels in your body.
If you have tested positive for COVID-19, a Health Department staff member will contact you within 48 hours of receiving your lab result. They will ask questions about your symptoms and if you have a pulse oximeter at home. If you do not have one, you will receive one within one to two days, generally. You will then be asked to use it to monitor your oxygen levels throughout the day. The Health Department will continue to regularly contact you over the next several days to ask what your oxygen levels were and about any symptoms you may have.

questionOriginal: Are children more susceptible to the COVID-19 virus? How can I help my children from getting sick?
questionText: Are children more susceptible to the COVID-19 virus? How can I help my children from getting sick?
answerOriginal:
No. Based on available evidence, children do not appear to be at higher risk for COVID-19 than adults. While some children and infants have been sick with COVID-19, adults make up most of the known cases to date. You can encourage your child to help stop the spread of COVID-19 by teaching them to do the same things everyone should do to stay healthy.

  • Socialize with household members or one other trusted household that is also taking health and safety precautions.

  • Wash hands often using soap and water or hand sanitizer with at least 60% alcohol.

  • Avoid people who are sick (coughing and sneezing).

  • Clean and disinfect high-touch surfaces daily in household common areas (like tables, hard-backed chairs, doorknobs, light switches, remotes, handles, desks, toilets, sinks).

  • Wash items including washable plush toys, according to the manufacturerâs instructions. If possible, wash items using the warmest appropriate water setting for the items and dry items completely. Dirty laundry from a person who is sick can be washed with other peopleâs items.

As of May 6, Vermonters are now allowed to gather in small groups of 10 or fewer people as long as health and safety precautions are followed. Members of one household may now choose to socialize â and allow children to play â with members of another trusted household that is also taking health and safety precautions. Learn how to safely connect with friends and family.

Find more resources for families with children and information from the CDC on caring for young children.
answerText:
According to the CDC, while fewer children have been sick with COVID-19 compared to adults, children can be infected with the COVID-19 virus, can get sick from COVID-19, and can spread the virus to others. Children, like adults, who have COVID-19 but have no symptoms can still spread the virus to others.
Most children with COVID-19 have mild symptoms or have no symptoms at all. However, some children can get severely ill from COVID-19. They might require hospitalization, intensive care, or a ventilator to help them breathe. In rare cases, they might die. Babies under 1 year old and children with certain underlying conditions may be more likely to have severe illness from COVID-19. Learn more from the CDC about COVID-19 in children and teens.
A few children have developed Multisystem Inflammatory Syndrome in Children (MIS-C). Currently, information about MIS-C is limited, and the CDC is working to learn more.
You can teach your children the prevention steps to keep from getting or spreading COVID-19:

Stay home if you are sick.
Wash your hands often.
Keep your social circle small.
Stay at least 6 feet apart.
Wear a mask (children over 2 who are able).
Get the COVID-19 vaccine (when it becomes available to children).

Socializing for children is important for their development and wellbeing. There are ways children can socialize but still stay safe from getting or spreading COVID-19.
Find more resources for families with children and information from the CDC for children, teens and young adults.
You can find information about cases across age groups along with other COVID-19 data on the Vermont Dashboard. More detailed information is in the Weekly Data Summaries, which include more details on who has been impacted by COVID-19 in Vermont. You can find out more about testing trends, outbreaks, pre-existing conditions and symptoms of Vermonters with COVID-19.

questionOriginal: Are bars and restaurants open?
questionText: Are bars and restaurants open?
answerOriginal:
On April 10, the Governor extended his order (effective Tuesday, March 17 at 2 p.m.) closing all bars and restaurants statewide until May 15.

Establishments can continue to offer food take out and delivery.

Find up-to-date guidance and mandatory health and safety requirements for bars, restaurants and food service from the Agency of Commerce and Community and Development (ACCD), which requires employees to wear non-medical cloth face masks or coverings (bandanna, scarf, or non-medical mask, etc.) over their nose and mouth when in the presence of others.

Find more health resources for businesses and read the Health & Safety Tips for Essential Businesses.

The ACCD wants to hear from all Vermont businesses impacted by the response to the COVID-19 virus. Please share your experiences on the ACCD Business Impact Form, which will help them assess the full impact as they work toward solutions.
answerText:
Restaurants, bars and clubs are open under certain health and safety requirements.
Find more information about restaurants, catering, food service, social clubs and bars from the Agency of Commerce and Community Development (ACCD).

questionOriginal: Why was the Johnson & Johnson vaccine paused?
questionText: Why was the Johnson & Johnson vaccine paused?
answerOriginal:
Vermont has resumed use of the Johnson & Johnson vaccine as of April 26. The FDA and CDC announced that they studied and confirmed that the Johnson & Johnson vaccine is recommended for people 18 years of age and older, and that the pause on its use since April 13 can be lifted.

The CDC announced the pause after reports of a small number of people developing a rare and severe type of blood clot called cerebral venous sinus thrombosis (CVST). This type of blood clot is found in the blood vessels that drain blood from the brain and is combined with low platelets.

There have been no reported cases of these side effects in Vermont.

The pause was necessary to give the CDCâs Advisory Committee on Immunization Practices time to review additional data about the reported side effects.

Vermontâs health care providers have been given information and guidance about the potential blood clotting symptoms and appropriate medical treatment. They will be given any updated guidance.

Although the side effects of concern are extremely rare, the FDA and CDC recommend that you should contact your health care provider right away if you develop severe headache, abdominal pain, leg pain or shortness of breath within three weeks of receiving the Johnson & Johnson vaccine. If you do not have a health care provider, call 2-1-1 to be connected to care, or contact the nearest federally qualified health center or one of Vermontâs free & referral clinics.

To register for an appointment or to change the one you already have, go online or call 855-722-7878. Certain participating pharmacy partners, including CVS and Walgreens, are making plans to also offer the Johnson & Johnson vaccine. You can contact those pharmacies directly to make an appointment or to reschedule.
answerText:
Vermont has resumed use of the Johnson & Johnson vaccine as of April 26. The FDA and CDC announced that they studied and confirmed that the Johnson & Johnson vaccine is recommended for people 18 years of age and older, and that the pause on its use since April 13 can be lifted.
The CDC announced the pause after reports of a small number of people developing a rare and severe type of blood clot called cerebral venous sinus thrombosis (CVST). This type of blood clot is found in the blood vessels that drain blood from the brain and is combined with low platelets.
There have been no reported cases of these side effects in Vermont.
The pause was necessary to give the CDCâs Advisory Committee on Immunization Practices time to review additional data about the reported side effects.
Vermontâs health care providers have been given information and guidance about the potential blood clotting symptoms and appropriate medical treatment. They will be given any updated guidance.
Although the side effects of concern are extremely rare, the FDA and CDC recommend that you should contact your health care provider right away if you develop severe headache, abdominal pain, leg pain or shortness of breath within three weeks of receiving the Johnson & Johnson vaccine. If you do not have a health care provider, call 2-1-1 to be connected to care, or contact the nearest federally qualified health center or one of Vermontâs free & referral clinics.

questionOriginal: Do I have to be a Vermont resident to get the COVID-19 vaccine?
questionText: Do I have to be a Vermont resident to get the COVID-19 vaccine?
answerOriginal:
Yes. You will need to provide your address to make an appointment for the COVID-19 vaccine. However, if you live in another state, you can still get a vaccine in Vermont if:

  • You work in Vermont.
  • Your primary health care provider is in Vermont.
  • You moved to Vermont within the last 6 months with the intention of becoming a resident.

Identification is not required to make or go to a vaccine appointment.

People who are 75 years and older and live, work, or access primary health care in Vermont are now eligible to get a vaccine. Make an appointment to get the COVID-19 vaccine.

Find out who will be eligible next.
answerText:
Yes. You will need to provide your address to make an appointment for the COVID-19 vaccine. However, if you live in another state, you can still get a vaccine in Vermont if:

You work in one of these occupations or settings in Vermont: health care personnel, child care worker, work in a school, or work in the public safety system.
You moved to Vermont within the last 6 months with the intention of becoming a resident.
You attend a college, university or other educational institution in Vermont (including boarding school).
You live in Vermont for part of the year.

If you are a resident of another state and have a primary care provider in Vermont, you are not eligible to get a vaccine in Vermont. This is because primary care providers do not have vaccine to give right now. You will need to get the vaccine in your home state.
Make an appointment to get the COVID-19 vaccine.

questionOriginal: Is it possible to get COVID-19 even if Iâm fully vaccinated?
questionText: Is it possible to get COVID-19 even if Iâm fully vaccinated?
answerOriginal:
Yes. COVID-19 vaccines are very effective at preventing serious disease, including hospitalization and death. But no vaccine is 100% effective. That means some people who are vaccinated may become infected with COVID-19. This is called a âvaccine breakthrough.â This happens with any vaccine including measles, mumps, flu and others.

As more people are vaccinated, it is likely that the number of people who get sick with COVID-19 even after getting vaccinated will increase, especially if the amount of COVID-19 virus in our communities remains high. This growing number may sound concerning, but this is expected. Fortunately, the percentage of people who get COVID-19 after being vaccinated should stay low. Among those who get COVID-19 after being vaccinated, few will get very sick.

Community Immunity

Vaccine protection is more than one person being vaccinated. The more virus going around in the community, the higher your chances of coming into close contact with someone who is sick with COVID-19. When enough people in a community are protected against a contagious disease, it's very hard for it to spread. It is this community immunity that helps protect us all from getting sick. This is why â until we reach community immunity and the amount of virus in our community goes down â our prevention steps are so important.

Variants

Scientific studies show that some vaccines may not work as well on some of the variants. Studies with people in real world conditions are ongoing. Variants are circulating in Vermont and the numbers of people getting sick with COVID-19 is rising. Vermontâs numbers are too small to make any conclusions about the role of variants and the infections among fully vaccinated people that we are seeing. The Health Department is working to increase our ability to sequence more samples and select certain samples, like those among fully vaccinated people to look at more closely.

Learn more from the CDC about:

  • What you should know about the possibility of COVID-19 illness after vaccination
  • Vaccine breakthrough cases
