questionOriginal: Is there a standby list for extra or leftover vaccine doses? Will the Health Department call me?
questionText: Is there a standby list for extra or leftover vaccine doses? Will the Health Department call me?
answerOriginal:
Please do not show up at state-run vaccine clinics to wait for extra doses. These clinics include those run by the Health Department, the National Guard, health care partners, Costco, Hannaford, Price Chopper, Rite Aid, Shaws and Walmart. Clinics cannot accept walk-ins. You need to have an appointment to get a vaccine. However, from time to time, some clinics will be able to accept walk-ins. When that happens, we will share that information on our website and on social media.

To help make sure we do not waste vaccine doses, state-run clinics make an estimate of how many doses may remain at the end of the day. If there is a possibility that there will be extra doses, then clinic staff will estimate how many may be available and call people who are currently scheduled for a future COVID-19 vaccine appointment to come in. We canât guarantee that you will get the vaccine earlier if you are called because the estimated number of available doses could change.

The Health Department will reach out to you if there is a certain clinic that needs people for a standby list. Please do not call the Health Department to be put on the standby list. If you made an appointment through the state registration system that is three weeks or more away, you may get a call to ask if you are interested in being on the standby list. The call may come from a Vermont number or may appear to come from another state. You will only need to answer âyesâ or âno.â You will not be asked for your contact information or any other personal information since you are already in our system.

You will not lose your scheduled vaccination appointment if you join the standby list. But please do not cancel your original appointment since we cannot guarantee you a vaccine even if you are called. If you do get your vaccine earlier, then the clinic staff will cancel your original appointment.

If you are called, you would need to be able to arrive 30 minutes before the end of the clinic. Youâll be told what that time is when you are called. Clinics happen both weekdays and some weekends and are held during the day and sometimes in the evening.
answerText:
Please do not show up at state-run vaccine clinics to wait for extra doses. These clinics include those run by the Health Department, the National Guard, health care partners, Costco, Hannaford, Price Chopper, Rite Aid, Shaws and Walmart. Clinics cannot accept walk-ins. You need to have an appointment to get a vaccine. However, from time to time, some clinics will be able to accept walk-ins. When that happens, we will share that information on our website and on social media.
To help make sure we do not waste vaccine doses, state-run clinics make an estimate of how many doses may remain at the end of the day. If there is a possibility that there will be extra doses, then clinic staff will estimate how many may be available and call people who are currently scheduled for a future COVID-19 vaccine appointment to come in. We canât guarantee that you will get the vaccine earlier if you are called because the estimated number of available doses could change.
The Health Department will reach out to you if there is a certain clinic that needs people for a standby list. Please do not call the Health Department to be put on the standby list. If you made an appointment through the state registration system that is three weeks or more away, you may get a call to ask if you are interested in being on the standby list. The call may come from a Vermont number or may appear to come from another state. You will only need to answer âyesâ or âno.â You will not be asked for your contact information or any other personal information since you are already in our system.
You will not lose your scheduled vaccination appointment if you join the standby list. But please do not cancel your original appointment since we cannot guarantee you a vaccine even if you are called. If you do get your vaccine earlier, then the clinic staff will cancel your original appointment.
If you are called, you would need to be able to arrive 30 minutes before the end of the clinic. Youâll be told what that time is when you are called. Clinics happen both weekdays and some weekends and are held during the day and sometimes in the evening.

questionOriginal: Can pets get COVID-19? Can I get COVID-19 from my pet?
questionText: Can pets get COVID-19? Can I get COVID-19 from my pet?
answerOriginal:
According to the CDC and based on the limited information available to date, the risk of animals spreading COVID-19 to people is low. There is no evidence that the COVID-19 virus can spread to people from the skin, fur or hair of pets. It appears that it can spread from people to animals in some situations, especially during close contact.

Until we learn more about how this virus affects animals, treat pets as you would other human family members to protect them from a possible infection.

Because there is a risk that people with COVID-19 could spread the virus to animals, the CDC recommends that pet owners limit their petâs interaction with people outside their household.

  • Keep cats indoors when possible and do not let them roam freely outside.
  • Walk dogs on a leash at least 6 feet away from others.
  • Avoid public places where large numbers of people gather.
  • Do not put masks on pets. Masks could harm your pet.

Talk to your veterinarian if your pet gets sick or if you have any concerns about your petâs health.

Learn more about what to do if you have pets from the CDC.

Read the COVID-19 FAQs for pet owners from the American Veterinary Medical Association.

questionOriginal: Are mass gatherings (ceremonies, events, fairs or festivals) allowed?
questionText: Are mass gatherings (ceremonies, events, fairs or festivals) allowed?
answerOriginal:
Vermonters are allowed to gather in groups of 25 or fewer people as long as health and safety precautions are followed. Choose other trusted households that are also taking health and safety precautions. Learn how to safely connect with friends and family.

Vermonters may hold yard sales and garage sales with 25 or fewer people. Hosts and visitors must keep a distance of at least 6 feet from others, and it is recommended that they wear cloth face masks or coverings.

Gatherings of more than 25 people are still prohibited. This includes weddings, graduation ceremonies, and other social gatherings.

All traditional fairs and festivals have been canceled until further notice.

Organized outdoor markets, like flea markets, must follow the farmers market guidance from the Agency of Agriculture, Food & Markets (AAFM).

Farmers markets and pick-your-own farms and orchards must follow best practices outlined by AAFM.

Starting June 26, event venues, arts, culture and entertainment venues, and restaurants can hold events, such as weddings, funerals and parties, with certain occupancy limits and health and safety precautions. Outdoor services, events, and gatherings are strongly preferred.

Find more information on the health and safety requirements for sectors that are open from the Agency of Commerce and Community Development (ACCD).

At any gathering or event, everyone should follow these general precautions:Â wear a cloth face mask or covering, keep aÂ 6-foot distance from others, wash their hands often, and stay home if they are sick.
answerText:
Currently, venues may only host religious ceremonies, wedding ceremonies, funerals and other essential gatherings, but not the receptions and parties that are often affiliated with these gatherings.
As part ofÂ Vermont's phased reopening plan, businesses are transitioning to universal guidance in two phases. Find out more aboutÂ large events and universal guidance from the Agency of Commerce and Community Development (ACCD).
Find out about the current social gathering restrictions in Vermont.
Learn more about wedding ceremonies.
Travel forÂ funeralÂ services is not considered essential. You will need to follow all travel guidanceÂ before you come to VermontÂ orÂ when you return to Vermont.
